Libya's Government of National Unity said it rejected the use of Libyan territory as a destination for deporting migrants without its knowledge or consent and there was no coordination with the US on the issue. Khalifa Haftar's Libyan National Army, which controls eastern Libya, also rejected the idea. [1]
  • New Jersey mayor ICE center arrest: On May 9, 2025, Mayor Ras Baraka, the Dem mayor of Newark, NJ, was arrested and charged with tresspassing at a privately run federal immigration detention center while three U.S. lawmakers were on site for an unannounced inspection. Baraka was arrested in a scuffle at the gate to the ICE facility. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Putting America First In International Environmental Agreements
  • Executive Order: Withdrawals the US from the Paris Agreement under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (Paris Climate Agreement), including all US funding to the agreement. The withdrawl process will take one year. The Paris Agreement is aimed at limiting long-term global warming to 2.7 F (1.5 C) above pre-industrial levels or, failing that, keeping temperatures at least well below 3.6 F (2 C) above pre-industrial levels (the world is currently at 2.3 F/1.3 C). Trump previously left the Paris Agreement in 2017 during his first term. The order also revoked the U.S. International Climate Finance Plan. [1] [2]
  • US withdraws from UN climate fund: On Mar 7, 2025, Trump withdrew the US from the UN climate damage fund, dedicated to helping poor and vulnerable nations cope with climate change-fuelled disasters. [1]
  • US withdraws from IMO: In April 2025, Trump also withdrew from talks with the U.N.'s International Maritime Organization (IMO), which aimed at reaching net zero shipping emissions by 2050. Shipping transports around 90% of world trade and accounts for nearly 3% of the world's carbon dioxide emissions.
  • Mass climate research firings: On April 20, 2025, Trump fired 400 contributors to the sixth National Climate Assessment, which is mandated by Congress under the Global Change Research Act of 1990. The National Climate Assessment is the U.S. government's signature study that informs federal and local governments on how to prepare for climate change impacts. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Application of Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act to TikTok
  • Orders the Attorney General to not enforce on the TikTok ban for 75 days. Trump said the order "just gave me the right to sell it or close it." [1] [2]
  • On Feb 13, 2025, TikTok returned to the Apple and Google app stores in the US. [3]
  • On April 4, 2025, Trump extended the TikTok EO by 75 more days. Earlier in the week, it was reported that a deal was finalized to make TikTok US owned but the deal torpedoed after Trump announced his reciprocal tariffs. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Withdrawing the United States from the World Health Organization
  • Executive Order: Withdrawls the US from the World Health Organization (WHO) due to their supposed handling of COVID. The withdrawl will take 1 year. The US contributed 18% of the funding to the WHO before Trump's withdrawl, being the biggest funder. The order also revoked Biden's COVID response executive order 13987 from Jan 2021. [1] [2]
  • Possible WHO reform On Feb 6, 2025, Trump began considering a plan to reform the WHO in order for the US to remain in the organization. Trump said the US could return if the WHO is "cleaned up", without providing details, and that if an American was places in charge of the organization when the current WHO director's term ends. [3]
  • WHO flu vaccine meeting: On Feb 28, 2025, the CDC and FDA took part in a WHO meeting to discuss the flu vaccine ahead of flu season, despite Trump's pullout. [1]
  • WHO layoffs: On May 14, 2025, WHO announced they had reduced its management team by half and will have to scale back operations due to the loss of US funding. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Restoring Accountability to Policy-Influencing Positions Within the United States Federal Workforce
  • Executive Order: Reinstated a previous Trump executive order 13957, also known as Schedule F. Schedule F allows Trump to reclassify federal workers' job status, in order to make it easier to fire them. The order order creates a new, much larger category of federal employees called "Schedule Policy/Career" who do not have the typical protections enjoyed by civil servants and can be fired at will. Also revoked a Biden executive order 14003 about protecting federal workers. Schedule F has its origins from the "unitary executive theory" that originated under Reagan during Iran-contra. Unitive executive theory says that president could fire officers in the executive branch at will, without any restraint from Congress. [1] [14]
  • Lawsuit against EO: The National Treasury Employees Union, which represents 150,000 employees in 37 federal agencies and departments, sued Trump for the order seeking to block it. [2]
  • Inspector generals purge: Days after signing the order, Trump fired the inspector generals of 17 different federal agencies, despite the law requiring a president to give Congress "substantive rationale, including detailed and case specific reasons" for a dismissal 30 days in advance. On Feb 12, 2025, 8 of the 17 inspectors general who were fired (including from the Departments of Defense, Veterans Affairs, Health and Human Services, State, Agriculture, Education and Labor, and the Small Business Administration), sued Trump for fireing them, saying he did so illegally. [5] [10]
  • Hampton Dellinger: On 2/7/2025, Trump fired the Hampton Dellinger, who was appointed in 2023 to head the Office of Special Counsel, a watchdog agency focused on protecting government whistleblowers, but was later reinstated by district judge Amy Berman Jackson for two weeks (later extended) after Hampton sued Trump for firing him illegally. On Feb 15, 2025, Trump's appeal to the temporary restraining order was rejected upon which Trump's DOJ asked the Supreme Court to lift the order to allow Trump to fire Dellinger. On Feb 21, 2025, the Supreme Court declined to let Trump immediately fire Dellinger. On Feb 25, 2025, 6 federal probationary workers that had been fired by DOGE earlier in the month (20,000 had been fired), had their jobs reinstated at the request of Dellinger, who said the employees had been fired illegally. On Mar 1, 2025, District Judge Amy Berman Jackson ruled that Trump's firing of Dellinger was illegal and that allowing the firing to go through would give him "a constitutional license to bully officials in the executive branch into doing his will." On Mar 5, 2025 Dellinger was removed from his post after the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit temporarily paused the previous order that reinstated him. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8]
  • Gwynne Wilcox: Trump also on the 28th, Trump fired Gwynne Wilcox, a Democratic member of the US National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) who was appointed by Biden, who voted to bar employers from holding mandatory anti-union meetings. Wilcox later sued Trump, saying federal law that allows a president to oust a board member only for neglect of duty or malfeasance in office under the Supreme Court ruling from the 1935 umphrey's Executor v. United States case. Federal judge Beryl Howell later ruled Wilcox's firing was illegal but this ruling was later overturned by an appeals court, saying the laws passed by Congress sheilding federal workers from being fired encroached on the president's power. On April 7, 2025, another appeals court ruled 7-4 to reinstate the TRO requiring Wilcox to be reinstated, saying the previous appeal court ruling had ignored Supreme Court precedent on the issue. On April 9, 2025, Chief Justice John Roberts issued a stay on the TRO while they considered weather to block it. [3] [14] [3] [4] [5]
  • Head of CFPB fired: On 2/1/2025, head of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), Rohit Chopra, was fired by Trump; Chopra had a reputation of being an aggressive watchdog who targeted the financial industry under Biden. On 2/3/2025, Trump named Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent as acting director of the CFPB, upon which he halted almost all CFPB activities including investigations, litigation, rulemaking and public communications. On 2/6/2025, Trump attempted to fire Federal Election Commission (FEC) Commissioner and Chair Ellen Weintraub, but she refused, saying that Trump was not firing her in a legal manner. [7] [4] [8]
  • Cathy Harris: On Feb 18, 2025, a Washington district judge issued a TRO preventing Trump from firing Cathy Harris from the Merit Systems Protection Board after she alleged Trump illegally fired her. The Merit Systems Protection Board is a three-member board that rules on reinstating workers who feel they have been fired incorrectly. The law that created the board allows members to be removed only for "inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office." On Mar 4, 2025, District Judge Rudolph Contreras ruled that Trump illegally fired Harris and she was reinstated, also saying the agency's "mission and purpose require independence." On Mar 28, 2025, Contreras' ruling was overturned by an appeals court, saying the laws passed by Congress sheilding federal workers from being fired encroached on the president's power. On April 7, 2025, another appeals court ruled 7-4 to reinstate the TRO requiring Harris to be reinstated, saying the previous appeal court ruling had ignored Supreme Court precedent on the issue. On April 9, 2025, Chief Justice John Roberts issued a stay on the TRO while they considered weather to block it. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5]
  • C.Q. Brown fired: On Feb 21, 2025, Trump fired chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Air Force General C.Q. Brown, in an unprecedented move. The chairman is meant to be apolitical and serve between multiple presidents, Brown's term was to end in 2027. Hegseth previously questioned if Brown would have gotten the position if he were not black. He also fired the head of the Navy and air force vice chief of staff Admiral Lisa Franchetti. In a suprise pick, Trump chose Dan Caine, a retired 3 star general, to be the next chairman; Caine was confimed by the Senate in a 60-25 vote in April 2025. On 2/27/2025, William Perry, Leon Panetta, Chuck Hagel, Lloyd Austin, and Beyond Mattis, all former defense secretaries, signed a scathing letter criticizing Trump's firing of Brown, saying he was making the military a political arm, and called for Congress not to confirm Dan Caine. On Feb 28, 2025, US Army Lieutenant General Telita Crosland, the head of the military's Defense Health Agency and one of the most senior Black female officers in the Army was forced to retire by the Trump admin after 32 years of service. On May 5, 2025, Hegseth further ordered a 25% reduction in four-star officers at the Pentagon. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6]
  • Economic committees terminated: On Mar 4, 2025, Trump terminated the Federal Economic Statistics Advisory Committee (FESAC) and the Bureau of Economic Analysis Advisory Committee. Both were expert committees who produced statistics for the US economy. The move will likely effect the quality of data. [1]
  • Adam Cohen fired: On March 8th, 2025, Trump fired Adam Cohen the director of organized crime drug enforcement task forces. The same day he also fired 3 attorneys who were working on the Eric Adams case. [1]
  • Susan Tsui Grundmann reinstated: On Mar 12, 2025, US District Judge Sparkle Sooknanan in DC ruled that Trump lacked the power to remove Dem member from the Federal Labor Relations Authority and ordered that Susan Tsui Grundmann be reinstated. The decision gives the FLRA a 2-1 Democratic majority until her term expires in July. Sooknanan said Trump's move had undermined Congress' goal of insulating the FLRA from politics. A DOJ lawyer at a hearing did not deny that Trump violated the law, but argued that the restrictions on the removal of FLRA members are unconstitutional. [1]
  • FTC purge: On Mar 18, 2025, Trump fired 2 Dem FTC commissioners, of the 5 total commissioners. FTC commissioners are appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate. A unanimous 1935 Supreme Court decision known as Humphrey's Executor, allows the firing of FTC commissioners only for good cause, such as neglecting their duties. [1]
  • General Timothy Haug: On April 3, 2025, Trump fired General Timothy Haugh from his nonpartisan position as director of the National Security Agency and reassigned his deputy at the NSA Wendy Noble. Haugh was not present in the leaked Signal group chat and was fired without explanation. Haugh's firing came a day after Laura Loomer met with Trump with a list of national security staff whom she said were disloyal. After Haugh's firing, Loomer denounced Haugh as "HAND PICKED by General Milley," Milley previously called Trump a "wannabe dictator." In April 7, 2025, U.S. Navy Vice Admiral Shoshana Chatfield, who holds a senior position in NATO, was also fired by Trump in his growing national security purge. [1] [2] [3]
  • Carla Hayden fired: On May 8, 2025, Trump fired the Librarian of Congress, Carla Hayden. Hayden was the first woman and first African American in the role and headed an office that management and policy responsibility for the library. Hayden was appointed under Obama for a 10-year term and had Senate confirmation. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Holding Former Government Officials Accountable For Election Interference And Improper Disclosure Of Sensitive Governmental Information
  • Executive Order: Revokes the security clearances of 50 former intelligence officials who signed a 2020 letter saying the Hunter Biden laptop story was likely Russian disinformation. Includes prominent names like ames Clapper, the director of national intelligence under Obama, John Brennan and Leon Panetta, who both served as CIA director under Obama, and John Bolton, who resigned as Trump's national security adviser during his first term. Bolton was given a protective Secret Service detail after Iran threatened to assassinate him. It is unclear if any of those on the list still maintained a security clearance, with the EO mainly serving as a public policy message to Trump's right-wing base [1] [2]
  • More Revokations: On Mar 21, 2025, Trump did another round of security clearance revocation, including Kamala Harris, Hillary Clinton, Joe Biden, Liz Cheney, Jake Sullivan, Fiona Hill, Mark Zaid, Adam Kinzinger. Former U.S. presidents have traditionally received intelligence briefings so they can advise incumbent presidents on national security and foreign policy. Biden previously revoked Trump's security clearance in 2021. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Clarifying The Military's Role In Protecting The Territorial Integrity Of The United States
  • Executive Order: Directs the Secretary of Defense to use the US Armed Forces to seal the border from the "invasion including unlawful mass migration, narcotics trafficking, human smuggling and trafficking, and other criminal activities". [3]
  • Troops sent to border: Following the order, Trump sent 1500 additional troops to the US-Mexico border, 2200 troops were already at the border. [1]
  • Military deports migrants: Trump also used US military aircraft to fly detained migrants to Guatemala. [2]
  • Colorado military base detention center: On 1/28/25, ICE began using a US military base in Colorado to detain migrants, housing migrants at military bases had previously been done by Biden and Trump. [4]
  • Guantanamo bay: On 1/29/25, Trump ordered the Pentagon and the Dept of Homeland Security in a memo to prepare to expand the already existing migrant facility at the US naval base at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba to hold as many as 30,000 migrants, the facility is seperate from the Guantanamo Bay prison that has been used by the US to torture suspected terrorists in the past. On 2/4/2025, the first US military aircraft carrying detained migrants headed to Guantanamo Bay. On Feb 9, 2025, a federal distruct judge in New Mexico issued a temporary block on the US military sending 3 Venezuelan men from being sent to Guantanamo. On Mar 1, 2025, the ACLU sued Trump trying to block him from transferring 10 migrants to Guantanamo, saying that they face harsh conditions, including isolation and abuse. On April 30, 2025, US District Judge Brian Murphy in Boston issued an order that Guantanamo held immigrants must have due process before being shipped off to El Salvador. The order came after a previous Murphy order that Venezuelans must get due process before being shipped to El Salvador's CECOT, Trump tried to skirt this by sending the Venezuealans to Guantanamo then El Salvador to bypass giving them any due process. [1] [2] [3] [4]
  • Spy satellites on border: On Mar 27, 2025, Reuters first reported that Trump had began contracting National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) and the National Reconnaissance Office (NRO) to oversee spy satellites and analyze imagery from the US southern border. [1]
  • Border land transfered to military: On April 14, 2025, the Trump admin announced an emergency transfer of a 110,000 acre strip of federal land on the US-Mexico border (known as the Roosevelt Reservation) to the US Army as part of a military base. Trump did this to allow troops to detain any trespassers, including migrants, to get around a federal law that prohibits U.S. troops from being used in domestic law enforcement on American soil. During Trump's first term, he made a similar move with 560 arces of land in order to build some of his border wall. [1] [2]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Unleashing American Energy
  • Orders the heads of all agencies to review existing regulations and policies and to suspend or rescind all of the regulations or policies that are too burdensome on domestical energy production. Revokes Biden executive orders 13990, 13992, 14008, 14007, 14013, 14027, 14030, 14037, 14057, 14057, 14072, 14082, and 14096, which were all related to climate change and clean energy. Terminates the American Climate Corps. Ends a non-binding Biden goal to have EVs make up half of new cars sold in the US by 2030. Revokes Jimmy Carter executive order 11991 from 1977, which was for enhancing environmental quality. Disbands the Interagency Working Group on the Social Cost of Greenhouse Gases (IWG), from Biden EO 13990. Terminates the "Green New Deal", pauses the disbursement of funds from the Inflation Reduction Act and Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act that go to electric vehicle charging stations or funding for electric vehicle grants. Directs the energy secretary to restart all applications for LNG export project for national security purposes. Directs government agencies to remove any burdensome environmental regulations on domestic mining. [1]
  • Trump says he expects the orders to help reduce consumer energy prices and improve US national security. The order seeks to ease environmental restrictions on power plants, speed up construction of new plants, and ease permitting for transmission and pipeline projects to meet the supply needed for the data center growth expected from AI in the coming years. [2] [3]
  • On Mar 5, 2025, Trump withdrew the US from the Just Energy Transition Partnership. The JETP is a collaboration between richer nations to help developing countries transition from coal to cleaner energy. [1]
  • In April 2025, the Trump admin said they would not longer require environmental impact statements for about 3,244 oil and gas leases across Colorado, Montana, New Mexico, North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah and Wyoming. [1]
  • On April 14, 2025, the USDA cut the Partnership for Climate-Smart Commodities, which allocated $3 bln to 135 projects in every state for soil health, carbon sequestration, reduced methane emissions and other climate-friendly practices. [1]
  • On April 16, 2025, US District Judge Allison Burroughs in Boston issued a TRO blocking the Dept of Energy from freezing funding to universities including MIT, Princeton, and Cal IT. The DoE had cut funding to the universities as part of Trump's broader order of cutting "indirect" research costs to universities. The DoE said this included $400 million in annual spending. [1]
  • On April 15, 2025, US District Judge Mary McElroy in Providence, Rhode Island, issued an injunction blocking Trump from freezing already-awarded and congressionally approved funding to climate change projects. The funding came from the Biden Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act of 2021 and his signature 2022 Inflation Reduction Act. Trump called for the funding to be cut as part of this EO. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Realigning the United States Refugee Admissions Program
  • Executive Order: Suspends the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program (USRAP). Says Dept of Homeland Security to make a report for Trump within 90 days in actions to resume refugee program. Revoked Biden executive order 14013, which seeked to resettle refugees and plan for climate change. [1]
  • DHS pauses refugee programs: After the order was signed, the Dept of Homeland Security paused several programs allowing immigrants to settle temporarily in the US. The pause demanded an immediate end to "final decisions" on certain visa applications pending a review by the Trump administration about whether to cancel the programs permanently. [2]
  • Afghan refugee program shutdown: In Feb 2025, the Trump admin directed the office (Coordinator for Afghan Relocation Efforts, CARE) responsible for resettling Afghan refugees to shut down. Ending the operation could leave 200,000 Afghans without paths to the US. [3]
  • Refugee resettlement program TRO On 2/26/2025, a US district judge, Jamal Whitehead, issued a TRO on Trump's EO, blocking him from suspending the US refugee resettlement program. Whitehead said Trump had overstepped his executive authority with the order. On Mar 24, 2025, Whitehead further ordered the Trump administration to stop terminating contracts with groups that assist with refugee resettlement and restore cancelled agreements. On Mar 25, 2025, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that Trump could pause refugee resettlement efforts while litigation over the freeze plays out in court. The ruling narrowed Whitehead's ruling, to allow Trump to freeze new refugee admissions, ones from before the EO must still be carried out. [1] [2] [3]
  • Rubio revokes Sudanese visas: On April 4, 2025, Rubio said he was revoking all visas for South Sudanese passport holders due to South Sudan failing to take them back fast enough. [1]
  • Iraqi refugee deported: On April 24, 2025, the US deported Omar Abdulsattar Ameen to Rwanda. Ameen was granted US refugee status in 2014 and had denied Iraqi government claims that he was an ISIL member who killed a police officer. In 2021, a judge found that the case against Ameen for the murder were "no plausible" due to him being in Turkey at the time of the murder but both Biden and Trump pursued his removal from the US, saying he lied on his refugee application by saying he had never interacted with ISIL. Rwanda has positioned itself as a destination country for migrants that Western countries would like to remove. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Protecting the Meaning and Value of American Citizenship
  • Ends birthright citizenship if (1) the mother is in the country illegally or legally but temporarily and father are not a US citizens. [1]
  • A day after the EO, 22 Dem-led states, the District of Columbia, and the city if San Fransisco sued Trump in Boston and Seattle and the American Civil Liberties Union immigrant organization also filed seperate lawsuits, both of which said Trump's order violated the 14th amendment. On 1/23/25, a Seattle US District judge, John Coughenour, blocked the order from being enforces for 14 days while the judge considers a long-term ruling. Coughenour said the order was "blatantly unconstitutional," referring to the 14th amendment that says any person born in the US is a citizen under the Citizenship Clause. On 2/6/2025, Coughenour extended his order, setting a nationwide injunction, saying Trump was ignoring the rule of law. Trump later appealed the order but was denied on Feb 19, 2025. Opponents of birthright citizenship say that if the drafters of the 14th amendment wanted all people born in the US to be citizens they would not have said that citizens "be subject to the jurisdiction" of the US. They argue that this language excludes people who entered the country illegally and, by implication, their children. However, most scholars dismiss the interpretation, since people in the country illegally are still subject to the laws of the US and are thus "subject to the jurisdiction" of the US. [1] [2] [3] [4] [6] [8]
  • On 2/5/2025, a second federal judge from a US District court in Maryland issued a nationwide order blocking Trump from implementing the birthright citizenship EO until the court had ruled on a lawsuit brought to the judge by the CASA and the Asylum Seeker Advocacy Project immigrant rights groups and 5 pregnant women. Trump appealed the Maryland court order but was denied on 2/28/2025. On 2/10/25, a third US district judge from New Hampshire blocked Trump's birthright EO, saying he expects the issue to be brought to the Supreme Court. [1] [2] [3]
  • On Mar 13, 2025, Trump asked the Supreme Court to narrow the 3 orders against him and that the injunctions should be scaled back from applying universally and should be limited to just the plaintiffs that brought the cases and are "actually within the courts' power." [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Restoring The Death Penalty And Protecting Public Safety
  • Directs the Attorney General to pursue the death penalty for all demanding crimes, Biden had previously issued a moratorium on Federal executions in 2021. Directs the Attorney General to pursue prosecution of the death penalty for murder of law-enforcement or a capital crime committed by an illegal alien in the US Directs the Attorney General to encourage state attorneys general to pursue the death penalty. Directs the Attorney General to imprison, the 37 people that Biden commuted their death sentences for life sentences, in the worst conditions possible. Directs the Attorney General to pressure the Supreme Court to overturn any precedents that limit federal or state authority to impose the death penalty. Directs the Attorney General to assist states in getting lethal injection drugs. Directs the Attorney General to prioritize prosecuting violent crime. During Trump's first term, he carried out 13 federal executions, more than any other president in modern history (only 3 others have been executed since 1976). [1] [2]
  • On Mar 7, 2025, South Carolina carried out an execution by firing squad, the first of its kind in 15 years. Brad Sigmon, chose to be killed by a firing squad, saying he feared the alternatives of the electric chair or lethal injection would risk a slower and more torturous death, he had been convicted for 2 murders. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Declaring a National Energy Emergency
  • Executive order: Declares a national energy emergency. Directs agencies to "facilitate the identification, leasing, siting, production, transportation, refining, and generation of domestic energy resources, including, but not limited to, on Federal lands." Directs the EPA to consider allowing year-round E15 gasoline. Directs agencies to use all emergency authorities to "expedite the completion of all authorized and appropriated infrastructure, energy, environmental, and natural resources projects," including new plants and pipelines. Directs the Army to use all emergency powers to increase energy production. States that the Endangered Species Act cannot be an obstacle to energy development, accelerating the potential decline of the extinction of whales and sea turtles. [1]
  • US energy production: Despite the US having record energy production and being the largest producer of energy of any nation in history, Trump felt the need to declare a national energy emergency. The order allows oil expansion through federal use of eminent domain and the Defense Production Act, which allow the government to use private land and resources to produce goods deemed to be a national necessity. On Feb 3, 2025, Interior Secretary Doug Burgum signed 6 orders in line with Trump's EO, Burgum's orders directed agency staff to identify emergency and legal authorities to speed project development and permitting, saying that it would eliminate at least 10 regulations for every new one introduced. [2] [3] [4]
  • Fast tracked permitting: On Feb 19, 2025, the Army Corps of Engineers listed 688 permits for energy and infrastructure projects that were to be fast tracked through their environmental approval process under the "energy emergency." The emergency permit allowed the projects to speed through an environmental review that would enable them to be built through wetlands. Among the permit applications included Enbridge's controversial Line 5 oil pipeline under Lake Michigan, natural gas power plants, transmission lines, mining and other infrastructure projects. [4]
  • EPA deregulation: On Mar 12, 2025, the EPA announced more than 30 deregulatory measures This included that they would narrow the definition of waterways that receive protection under the Clean Water Act - a move that could ease limits on runoff pollution from agriculture, mining, and petrochemicals. Zeldin also said he would review Biden-era clean power plant rule that seeks to reduce carbon emissions from power plants to fight global warming and would also roll back greenhouse gas emissions standards for heavy- and light-duty vehicles for model year 2027 and later. The EPA also said it will take steps to undo a scientific finding from 2009 that greenhouse gas emissions endanger public health, a provision that forms the bedrock of the EPA's greenhouse-gas regulations so far, the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act codified language deeming greenhouse gases are air pollutants. The "endangerment finding" came as a result of a Supreme Court ruling in the 2007 Massachusetts v. EPA case that greenhouse gases are covered by the Clean Air Act. Other measures the EPA said they would take include revisiting Biden-era standards to reduce soot and air particulate matter, dialing back regulations for the oil and gas industry (including required reporting of methane emissions), and allowing the reuse of drilling wastewater, potentially for agriculture and industry. [1]
  • EPA clawback lawsuit: On Mar 18, 2025, US District Judge Tanya Chutkan issued a TRO on the EPA's termination of three environmental nonprofit groups' grant agreements and barring Citibank from dispersing grant funding held at the bank in their accounts. Chutkan said that the EPA had asserted substantial fraud, waste, and abuse with the contracts but only provided vague assertions to back up that claim. The grants were terminated as part of Zeldin's campaign to claw back money from the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund, part of the Inflation Reduction Act, aimed at curbing pollution. The three groups are Climate United, Coalition for Green Capital and Power Forward Communities. [1]
  • Princeton climate funding cut: On April 8, 2025, Trump cut $4 mln in funding to Princeton that was for assessing climate-related risks. [1]
  • Emergency permitting: On April 23, 2025, the Trump admin said it would implement an emergency permitting process for energy and mining projects on federal lands, slashing approval times that typically take months or years to at most 28 days. The DOI said the emergency procedures would apply to fossil fuels like oil, gas and coal, uranium, geothermal, critical minerals, biofuels and kinetic hydropower projects and did not list solar energy or wind energy, which Trump has called expensive and ugly. On May 2, 2025, 10 more mining projects were added to the fast track list [1] [2]
  • Forever chemicals: On May 14, 2025, the EPA rescinded much of the Biden administration's first nationwide drinking water standard aimed at protecting people from toxic "forever chemicals" known as PFAS found in many household items. The EPA will only maintain current limits on two of these chemicals. "Forever chemicals" are not easily broken down in the human body or environment. The Biden rule set limits for five individual PFAS chemicals: PFOA, PFOS, PFNA, PFHxS, and HFPO-DA and gave all public water systems three years to complete monitoring for these chemicals and required them to inform the public of the level of PFAS measured in their drinking water. [1]
  • Wind and solar deregulation: On May 14, 2025, Trump began to rescind a Biden-era regulation that lowered fees for renewable energy projects on federal lands, saying the rule unfairly favored development of wind and solar facilities. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 14168 Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government
  • Executive Order: Recognizes 2 sexes: male and female, where these sexes are not changeable. Says "female" is a person "that produces the large reproductive cell" and "male" is a person "that produces the small reproductive cell" as conception. Orders federal agencies to only use the word "sex" instead of "gender" in all federal documents. Orders agencies to remove all "gender ideology" policies and prohibits federal funds for "gender ideology". Says males cannot be housed in women prisons. Orders the Assistant to the President for Legislative Affairs to draft legislation to codify the defenitions from this EO. Rescinds Biden EOs 13988, 14004, 14020, 14021, and 14075 and dissolves the White House Gender Policy Council established by Biden EO 14020. [1]
  • Scrubbing of "gender ideology": Trump later ordered federal agencies in a memo to scrub mentions of "gender ideology" in contracts, job descriptions and social media accounts in line with this EO and place on leave any employee "whose position description involves inculcating or promoting gender ideology." Following the memo, the CDC and other federal health agencies took down webpages with info on HIV stats on trans people, health disparities among LGBT youth, and the Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System database that tracks trends in teen tobacco use, teen pregnancy, and unsafe sexual behavior. On Feb 2, 2025, the CDC withdrew all scientific papers involving CDC researchers from external journals to allow Trump to review for words including gender, transgender, LGBT and nonbinary to ensure they complied with only recognizing 2 sexes in line with this EO. On Feb 19, 2025, RFK Jr ordered all HHS departments to update terms like sex, male, and female in line with Trump's EO. [2] [5] [6]
  • Trans people in prisons: On 1/26/25, a trans woman, known by the pseudonym Maria Moe, serving time in federal prison sued Trump soon after he signed the EO, saying it violated the constitution. On 1/30/25, a Boston district judge temporarily blocked federal prisons from transferring Maria Moe to a men's prison and denying her gender-affirming care, her laywers argued that Trump's EO went against the 5th amendment (discriminating based on sex) and the 8th amendment (cruel and unusual punishment). [3] [4]
  • Witholding art funding: On April 3, 2025, US District Judge William Smith in Providence, Rhode Island declined to issue a TRO blocking Trump from witholding National Endowment for the Arts funding to arts organizations that promote "gender ideology." Smith said the TRO is not needed since the NEA had already reversed their policy to withold funding after the ACLU filed their lawsuit. [1]
  • Trans passport policy: On April 18, 2025, US District Judge Julia Kobick in Boston issued a preliminary injunction, that ordered Trump to allow six trans plaintiffs to obtain passports consistent with their gender identities. Kobick declined to make the injunction nationwide. Kobick said Trump's policy of refusing to issue passports to transgender and nonbinary Americans that reflect their gender identities is likely unconstitutional. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 14169 Reevaluating And Realigning United States Foreign Aid
  • Executive Order: Institutes a 90-day pause on US foreign development assistance (the US is the largest single donor of aid globally at 42%, giving $72 billion in 2023, which was less than 1% of its total budget). Assistance includes to foreign countries from USAID and to foreign NGOs. Orders a review of all assistance programs that aren't "America First" during the 90 day pause. [1]
  • USAID: During Trump's first term, in 2017, he tried to move USAID to the State Department, but was blocked by Congress on a bipartisan opposition. USAID was established by a law from Congress so Trump cannot unilaterally dismantle it or move it into the State Department. [16]
  • USAID Impact: Following the order, clinics at camps in Thailand providing shelter for about 100,000 refugees from Myanmar were ordered to shutdown. Former head of USAID says 20 million people living with HIV get drugs from USAID to stay alive. A week after the order, Marco Rubio issued a waiver for live-saving humanitarian assistance during the 90 day pause, despite the waiver, numerous cases of life-saving aid not being delivered remained, due to a breakdown in communication at USAID from Trump's overhaul. Many aid workers erred on the side of caution and closed their aid programs since the US government became unresponsive to them in weather their programs qualified as "life-saving." The aid shutdown threw the aid industry into a frenzy, as contractors usually front the costs and then bill the U.S. government, hundreds of aid contractors beginning to lay off employees. Real world effects: aid was stopped to civil war and disaster ridden Myanmar, anti-malaria spraying campaigns were halted in Ghana and Kenya, AIDS treatment in Haiti was paused, hospitals and health clinics in Tailand housing Myanmar refugees in 7 camps closed. USAID had also been a funder of free journalism throughout the world, with non-Cuban-government media outlets CubaNet and Diario de Cuba losing their funding (USAID funded $2.3 million in 2024 to independent Cuban media). By Feb 2025, the US Disaster Assistance Response Teams, or DARTs (highly trained staff for disaster relief), working in Afghanistan, Gaza, Sudan and Ukraine were forced to shutdown after losing the ability to function due to USAID being destroyed. In Mar 2025, Trump cut funding to Gavi ($300 mln annually), a group that provides vaccines for children in poor countries, and would scale back its anti-malaria efforts. US universities who study agriculture were hit especially hard by the USAID cuts too, losing billions in funding and being forced to cut researchprograms. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8]
  • In FY2024, USAID had $44.20 billion in budgetary resources and obligated $24.86 billion of that, their actual outlays paid out were $334.90 million. This was distributed among USAID's 4 subcomponents: agency for internaional development, international security assistance, other, and special assistance initiatives. Agency for Internaional Development: $27 billion in budget, $16.6 in obligations, $14 billion in outlays. International Security Assistance: $16.4 billion in budget, $8 billion in obligations, $9.5 billion in outlays. Other: $80 million in budget, $50.8 million in obligations, $64 million in outlays. Special Assistance Initiatives: $87,327 in budget, $0 in obligations, $0 in outlays. [15]
  • Misinformation:
    • WH press secretary Karoline Leavit said USAID spent "$1.5 million to advance DEI in Serbia's workplaces; $70,000 for the production of a DEI musical in Ireland; $47,000 for a transgender opera in Colombia, $32,000 for a transgender comic book in Peru." The WH also posted a fact sheet titled "At USAID, Waste and Abuse Runs Deep," claiming USAID spent "$2.5 million for electric vehicles for Vietnam, $2 million for sex changes and LGBT activism in Guatemala, $6 million to fund tourism in Egypt, Hundreds of thousands of dollars for a non-profit linked to designated terrorist organizations — even AFTER an inspector general launched an investigation, Millions to EcoHealth Alliance — which was involved in research at the Wuhan lab, Hundreds of thousands of meals that went to al Qaeda-affiliated fighters in Syria, Funding to print personalized contraceptives birth control devices in developing countries, Hundreds of millions of dollars to fund irrigation canals, farming equipment, and even fertilizer used to support the unprecedented poppy cultivation and heroin production in Afghanistan, benefiting the Taliban."
      • The $1.5 million in advancing DEI in Serbia workplaces by promoting LGBT in Serbia was obligated in Oct 2022, with $0 outlays as of Feb 2025.
      • The others were not USAID, they were awarded under the State Department's Office of the Under Secretary for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs.
      • In 2022, $70,884 was obligated to an Irish company for "a live musical event to promote the U.S. and Irish shared values of diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility," $0 has been outlayed.
      • In 2021, $25,000 was obligated to a Columbian university "to raise awareness and increase the transgender representation" through the production of an opera, $0 has been outlayed and the other $22,000 came from non-federal funding.
      • In 2022, $32,000 was obligated to a Peruvian organization funding "a tailored-made comic, featuring an LGBTQ+ hero to address social and mental health issues." $0 has been outlayed.
    • Media outlets have also been targeted: [1] [2] [3] [4] [5]
      • In Feb, 2025, Trump swapped out NBC, NPR, NYT, Politico, CNN, The Washington Post, the Hill, and the War Zone for OAN, Breitbart, the New York Post, HuffPost, the Washington Examiner, the Free Press, the Daily Caller, and Newsmax in the Pentagon's dedicated press corps workspace
      • BBC: was claimed that BCC received $3.2 million during the 2023-2024 financial year but that money didn't go to its news operation. It went to BBC Media Action, an international charity that is “part of the BBC family,” but editorially and financially separate from BBC News.
      • Politico: was claimed that Politico received $8 million from USAID in 2024 but USAID only obligated Politico $44,000 in for news subscriptions. Politico was obligated $8 million in total for FY2024 from all US agencies combined, with none of that money coming from subsidies.
      • Associated Press: was claimed that AP received subsidies from USAID but USAID had $0 in obligations to the AP in all history.
      • Reuters: Musk and Trump both claimed Reuters was paid $9 million for "large scale social deception" by the DoD; the contract in question began in 2018 under Trump's first term. However, the contract was with Thomson Reuters Special Services (TRSS), which is a seperate legal entity Reuters news with a seperate board of directors, and was intended to protect the US government from social engineering, not to do it themselved. TRSS was selected for the contract as the evaluator to test the defensive tools the US government had against social engineering, so the US government could be protected from social engineering attacks. The term "Large Scale Social Deception" was the name of the "red team" proposal, where TRSS was to simulate an adversarial attack by pretending to be the enemy.
      • Subscriptions: On Feb 19, 2025, the Trump admin paused all news subscriptions other then for medical journals. They said they were prioritizing the termination of contracts with the Economist, the New York Times, Politico, Bloomberg News, the Associated Press and Reuters.
    • USAID funded Wuhan Lab leak [1]
      • Musk and Trump have both said that USAID sent funds to EcoHealth Alliance, a medical research group that funded the Wuhan lab in China where lab leakers believe COVID-19 originated from.
      • USAID only has 2 grants with EcoHealth, one that was from Oct 2021 with a $13 million obligation and $6.3 million in outlays. The other was from 2013 for "LAND USE CHANGE & DISEASE EMERGENCE", it has $2.5 million obligated and $0 outlayed.
      • The 2021 grant focused on "conserving threatened and endangered species by strengthening proected areas"
      • USAID later announced they would partner with EcoHealth for their PREDICT program, to mitigate Influenza, HIV/AIDS, SARS, and Influenza H1N1 in animal species.
    • $50 million to Gaza condoms [1] [2]
      • The WH also claimed that stopped two $50 million buckets of "aid" for Gaza via the International Medical Corps
      • However, IMC said "No US government funding was used to procure or distribute condoms, nor provide family-planning services."
      • IMC said that $68,078,508 from USAID to support Gaza since October 7, 2023, which they used to operate 2 field hospitals in central Gaza.
      • Under Biden a $50 million deal was signed for healthcare in Gaza, but this didn't include condoms
      • USAID did send $60.8 million in contraception in FY2023, but none were to Gaza. Under Trump's first term $51 million work of contraceptives were sent by USAID worldwide.
  • On Feb 3, 2024, DOGE leader Elon Musk said in an X space that Trump agreed to shut down USAID, with Musk saying "It's beyond repair." The Musk announcement came after the Trump admin placed, 2 top security chiefs at USAID: director of USAID security, John Voorhees, and his deputy, on leave after they refused to turn over classified material to Musk's DOGE team, which DOGE eventually got a hold of despite lacking the security clearance to do so. The FBI later said they were investigating the "targeting" of Elon's staff in relation to the USAID incident, the FBI normally doesn't public discuss investigations until charges are brought. In the same X space, Musk said he would cut $1 trillion from the budget in 2025, saying that "professional foreign fraud rings" were stealing large sums of money from the US, without giving evidence or explaining how he reached the $1 trillion figure. [4] [5] [6]
  • On Feb 2, 2024, the USAID website was taken offline without explanation. In the previous week there was almost 100 senior USAID staff that were put on leave by Trump, Matt Hopson, who had just been appointed as USAID chief of staff by Trump also resigned following the DOGE incident. On Feb 4, 2025, Trump announced that all USAID employees would be put on leave, with the exception of some personnel "responsible for mission-critical functions, core leadership and specially designated programs." On Feb 7, 2025, the Trump admin said that USAID would only keep 611 of their 10,000 federal employees with the cuts to take effect on that night at midnight. [6] [7] [10] [12]
  • On Feb 4, 2025, a group of Dem lawmakers held a protest outside the USAID headquarters after headquarters remained locked to employees by Trump, Trump also made Marco Rubio acting USAID head as well. On mar 5, 2025, hundreds of diplomats at the State Department and USAID wrote a letter to Rubio protesting the dismantiling of the agency, saying it would undermine US leadership and security. [1] [2]
  • On Feb 6, 2025, the American Federation of Government Employees (largest US government workers' union) and the American Foreign Service Association (association of foreign service workers) sued the Trump for his effort to dismantle USAID. The lawsuit was filed in Washington DC and alleged that Trump's actions were unconstitutional as Congress is the only entity lawfully permitted to dismantle an agency, the lawsuit seeked to restore USAID's previous funding. USAID was previously been established as an independent agency in 1988 by a law passed by Congress. A day later, on Feb 7, 2025, the judge, Carl Nichols, of the lawsuit issued a temporary pause (later extended to Feb 21) on aspects of Trump's order untin Feb 14, allowing 2700 USAID workers to return to work, but declined the union's request to reopen USAID buildings and restore funding for agency grants and contracts. On Feb 21, 2025, Nichols lifted the TRO due to the USAID workers not being in danger overseas, clearing the was for Trump to place the 2700 USAID workers on leave. [1] [2] [3] [4]
  • However, on Feb 23, 2025, after Nichols lifted the TRO on 2/21, Trump placed all USAID staff on paid leave, except leaders and critical staff, and eliminated 1600 positions. [1]
  • On Feb 10, 2025, the inspector general for USAID, Paul Martin, published a report critical of Trump for moving to eliminate the agency. The report said Trump's move to dismantle USAID has crippled the IG's ability to conduct oversight of unspent aid worth $8.2 billion. The next day, Martin was fired by Trump with no justification. [16]
  • On Feb 13, a US disctrict judge, Amir Ali, ordered Trump to restore funding for hundreds of foreign aid contractors. The lawsuit was brought by two aid organizations that receive funding from the US government, they argued that Trump's rationale for the freeze, which was to review all aid programs, was not a necessary presursor to achieve his goal. On Feb 20, 2025, the same judge, ordered Trump officials to comply with his previous order due to them not following it, stopping short of holding them in contempt of court. On Feb 25, 2025, Ali's ordered for a third time, for the funds to be unfrozen, which the Trump admin appealed, saying it "cannot" meet Ali's deadline (Wed 11:59pm 2/26) to unfreeze the funds. The appeal said that the delay in unfreezing was due to a new approval process the Trump admin was using to ensure payments aligned with Trump's agenda, which Ali already ruled was an invalid reason for delaying the payments. [1] [2] [3] [4]
  • On Feb 26, 2025, Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts, ordered that Ali's deadline be placed on hold, without providing any reationale for why. In a new filing, the Trump team said their review of USAID grants had been completed, with them canceling 5,800 awards, while keeping more than 500, and the State Department canceling another 4,100 awards, while keeping about 2,700. According to government documents, the Trump admin cut 80% of USAID programs as part of the review, 898 programs would remain active ($78 bln) and 5341 would be cut ($76 bln). Among the projects that were cut included UNAIDS, the Stop TB Partnership, Scaling Up Nutrition, malaria orgs, HIV/AIDS orgs, other TB orgs. What remained of USAID was moved into the State Department. [1] [2]
  • On Mar 5, 2025, the Supreme Court ruled 5-4 in favor of Ali's ruling that Trump could not withhold payment to foreign aid organizations for work they already performed for the government. Barrett and Roberts joined the liberal judges in the vote. On Mar 6, 2025, Judge Ali set a new deadline for the payments to be released on 3/10/2025. [1] [2]
  • On Mar 10, 2025, Ali declined to order Trump to restore thousands of foreign aid contracts and grants that have been canceled since the president took office but said that the money Congress had allocated to the contracts must be spent, just not on those specific contracts. Ali also ordered Trump to speed up the $2 billion in foreign aid payments to programs that had already been outlayed and give a timeline of funds being restored since Trump failed to meet his 3/10 deadline. [1]
  • On Mar 11, 2025, USAID's acting executive secretary, Erica Carr, ordered employees to shred large volumes of records for "clearing classified safes and personnel documents." "Shred as many documents first, and reserve the burn bags for when the shredder becomes unavailable or needs a break," Carr wrote in the email. Unions who later asked a judge to block the diective, saying it "suggests a rapid destruction of agency records on a large scale" that violates federal record-keeping law and could destroy evidence of Trump dismantling USAID. On Mar 13, the unions dropped their bid to have the directive blocked after being assured by Trump that no personal records wound be destroyed that the documents were largely from other agencies and were no longer needed. [1] [2]
  • On Feb 28, 2025, Nicholas Enrich, USAID's acting assistant administrator for global health, sent an internal memo to USAID saying that "political leadership" made it impossible to deliver lifesaving aid around the world, contradicting Trump and Rubio assurances that this was not the case. 20 min later Enrich was terminated, he was previously put on administrative leave on 2/26. Enrich said in his memo the aid block prevented efforts to contain Ebola in Uganda, resulting in 2 deaths and 10 infections. Enrich also said in his memo that since Feb 14, "zero lifesaving health activities" had been approved and the livesaving programs that had waivers could not continue due to DOGE cutting their access to the USAID payment systems. [1]
  • On Mar 18, 2025, Bill Gates met with Trump NSC officials to lobby them to continue aid through USAID, saying his Foundation could not fill in the gaps. Gates focused on organizations such as Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, as well as the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, and asked Trump to rejoin the WHO. [1]
  • On Mar 18, 2025, US District Judge Theodore Chuang in Maryland ordered Musk and DOGE to restore access to USAID's computer systems for its direct and contract employees, including thousands who were placed on leave. The plaintiffs of the lawsuit claimed that Musk seized control of USAID and effectively acted as a US officer, violating the Constitution's requirement that such officers be nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate, meaning Musk and DOGE had overstepped the authority of the executive branch of government, by effectively gutting an agency established by Congress. Trump's defense team argued that Musk's role is strictly as an adviser to Trump and DOGE was not responsible for agency actions since the actions were made by agency officials, but Chuang found that this was not the case and Musk/DOGE had effectively exercised direct control over USAID. Chuang ruled that Musk and DOGE "likely violated the United States Constitution in multiple ways, and that these actions harmed not only plaintiffs, but also the public interest." On Mar 28, 2025, an appeals court overturned Chuang's ruling, saying that Musk could go forward with further cuts to USAID and that he likely did not violate the constitution. [1] [2]
  • On Mar 19, 2025, Pete Marocco, who played a major role in dismantling USAID while serving as deputy administrator-designate at the agency, will return to the State department. Marocco was replaced by Jeremy Lewin, who is a DOGE staffer. [1]
  • On Mar 28, Trump announced he was cutting the remaining jobs at USAID not required by law but would still provide $9 mln in assistance to Myanmar following a devistating earthquack that killed 3300. Despite this, Trump fired 3 USAID workers in Myanmar who were helping with the earthquake response. When DOGE sent out termination letters to the remaining USAID staff, they were rittled with errors affecting pensions and severance pay, resulting in DOGE having to recall and resend the notices, which also contained errors. [1] [2] [3]
  • Reinstating food programs: On April 8, 2025, Trump reinstated 6 cancelled USAID contracts for emergency food assistance following internal and Congressional pressure. The contracts include awards to the World Food Programme in Lebanon, Syria, Somalia, Jordan, Iraq and Ecuador ($463 million) and four awards to the International Organization for Migration in the Pacific region. WFP funding for Yemen and Afghanistan was not restored. Previously, the contracts had been cancelled, reinstated, then cancelled again. [1]
  • Cancelling agriculture programs: On May 14, 2025, the USDA cancelled existing grants under its Food for Progress food aid program, which sends U.S. commodities abroad for agricultural and economic development projects, providing an important foreign market for farmers and enhancing food security in poorer countries. The US issued $218 million in Food for Progress grants in 2024. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Unleashing Alaska's Extraordinary Resource Potential
  • Directs agencies to expidite permitting and leasing of energy and natural resource projects in Alaska by rescinding any regulations in the way. Orders the prioritization of liquified natural gas (LNG) projects. The order reverses Biden's efforts to protect Arctic lands and US coastal waters from drilling [1] [2]
  • Also on Feb 19, 2025, several environmental groups sued Trump, aiming to block him from allowing offshore oil drilling in the the Arctic and Atlantic oceans. The groups seeked to keep Biden's orders in place and prevent Trump from reversing them. [3]
  • On Mar 20, 2025, Burgum announced steps to open up more acreage for oil and gas leasing and lift restrictions on building an LNG pipeline and mining road in Alaska. This included plans to reopen the 82% of Alaska's National Petroleum Reserve that is available for leasing for development and reopen the 1.56-million-acre Coastal Plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil and gas leasing. It also included that revokation of restrictions on land along the Trans-Alaska Pipeline Corridor and Dalton Highway by giving the land to the State of Alaska (Republican and wants to drill), which would pave the way forward for the proposed Ambler Road (which Biden rejected) and the Alaska Liquefied Natural Gas Pipeline project. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Protecting The United States From Foreign Terrorists And Other National Security And Public Safety Threats Orders the Secretary of State to enhance, accross all agencies, the vetting and screening of all aliens coming into the US or already in the US. The order set a 60-day window for agency officials to identify country's whose screening processes are "so deficient as to warrant a partial or full suspension on the admission of nationals from those countries." The American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee (ADC) said this new order relied on the same statutory authority used to justify Trump's 2017 travel ban, warning that a Muslim Ban 2.0 could be coming. [1] [2]
    1/20/2025 EO 141 Ending Radical And Wasteful Government DEI Programs And Preferencing
  • Executive Order: Directs the OBM and OPM to terminate all DEI programs in the federal government. [1]
  • Baltimore sues Trump: On Feb 3, 2025, the city of Baltimore and three other groups sued Trump for his DEI EOs in a US Maryland District court to halt and declare them unconstitutional due to Trump usurping budget power from Congress. [2]
  • DEI CIA Officers fired: On Jan 20, 2025, 51 CIA officers who had been assigned to work in DEI were terminated. District Court Judge Anthony Trenga later declined to issue a TRO on their firings after 21 of the officers sued Trump. On Mar 31, 2025, Trenga ordered that 19 of the officers fired be placed on administrative leave with full pay and benefits while the legal process plays out. [1] [2]
  • Environmental justice program cut: On Feb 6, 2025, Trump placed 168 employees who work in environmental justice programs on leave at the EPA, in a move in line with this EO. AG Pam Bondi also issued a memo at the DOJ announcing they would rescind all Biden-era environmental justice directives, with 4 employees working on environmental justice being places on leave. On the same day, Trump sent a memo ordering the review of funding for all NGOs that receive federal funding. [3] [4]
  • DEI in the NFL: The week before the 2025 Super Bowl, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell, said he had no plans to scale back NFL diversity programs. However, the league chose not to put the phrase "End Racism" behind one of the end zones, something it has done since 2021, replacing that directive with another one: "Choose Love." In the 2024 Super Bowl, Trump ran ads saying "Kamala's for they/them; President Trump is for you." [5]
  • DEI contracting TRO: On 2/21/25, a US district judge Adam Abelson blocked Trump from banning DEI programs in government agencies and on those who contracted with the US government, saying it was anti-First amendment and anti-free speech. Trump had been sued in the Maryland district court by the city of Baltimore and 3 other groups. On Mar 14, 2025, Virginia-based 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said Trump could temporarily implement his ban on DEI while the case was decided, overturning Abelson's TRO. [1] [2]
  • "Dear Colleague" letter: On Feb 14, 2025, the Dept of Education sent out a memo ordering the agency to withhold funding from schools that teach lessons about systemic racism and other so-called DEI topics and in April 2025 they ordered all public schools to end any DEI policies or lose funding. On Feb 25, 2025, the American Federation of Teachers and the American Sociological Association sued Trump, seeking to block the DoE memo. On Feb 27, 2025, the Dept of Education launched a portal to "End DEI," allowing the public to submit complaints about DEI initiatives in K-12 schools. On Mar 10, 2025, US District Judge Myong Joun in Boston issued a TRO on Trump's termination of $600 million in federal grants to train teachers to address teacher shortages in rural and underserved communities that Trump said were included "divisive ideologies," which it said included DEI, "critical race theory" and "anti-racism." On Mar 21, 2025, Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals rejected Trump's bid to have the TRO paused and directed the DOE to restore the $600 mln in grants. On April 4, 2025, the Supreme Court ruled 5-4 to put on hold Joun's TRO, saying administration is "likely to succeed in showing the district court lacked jurisdiction to order the payment of money." On April 24, 2025, 3 seperate US District judges Judge Landya McCafferty in NH, Judge Stephanie Gallagher in Baltimore, and Judge Dabney Friedrich in DC issued orders blocking Trump from cutting funding to schools that had "DEI programs." [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7]
  • Corporate DEI task force: On Feb 26, 2025, the FTC started a new task force probe potential corporate collusion in DEI. [1]
  • 400 EPA DEI grants cut: On March 10, 2025 the EPA said they had cut 400 environmental justice and diversity, equity and inclusion grants totaling $1.7 billion. These grants included funding for energy-efficient affordable homes, weatherized and retrofitted homes in Union Heights (one of first Black communities after emancipation). Also cut was a grant to the predominantly Latino community of San Diego's Barrio Logan, who had high rates of asthma due to close proximity to a major highway, which would fund EV busses and upgrades to air quality. The EPA also withdrew a Biden-era lawsuit against a synthetic rubber plant's Japanese owners, Denka Performance Elastomer LLC, siding with company lawyers, the Biden admin claimed the plant posed an imminent public health hazard due to emissions of chloroprene being a likely human carcinogen. On April 29, 2025, the EPA said they were in the process of cancelling 781 grants, including all environmental justice ones, almost double what was originally reported. [1] [2] [3]
  • University DEI programs: On Mar 14, 2025, the DOJ opened an investigation into 45 universities, citing complaints that the schools engaged with a program that set eligibility based on race. On Mar 27, Michigan University closed their DEI office, after previously spending $250 mln in 2024 on DEI, citing the need to comply wth Trump's EO to continue recieving funding. [1] [2]
  • Removal of ban on segregated facilities: On Mar 18, 2025, NPR reported that the Trump admin sent a memo, removing an explicit ban on "segregated facilities" like waiting rooms, restaurants and drinking fountains for federal contractors back in Feb 2025. The memo's step was largely symbolic as federal and state laws still outlaw discrimination and segregation. [1]
  • Labor Dept DEI grants TRO: On Mar 27, 2025, US District Judge Matthew Kennelly in Chicago issued an order to temporarily allow Labor Department grant recipient, Chicago Women in Trades (CWIT), to continue their DEI programs, citing First Amendment violations. [1]
  • DOJ cuts: On April 23, 2025, the DOJ cut 365 grants worth $811 million for supporting crime victims, including for transgender victims; hotlines used by crime victims; grants to fight human trafficking that have gone to organizations working with immigrants; programs to curb juvenile delinquency and safeguard incarcerated youth; and funding for state-run hate-crime reporting. The cuts were authored by Tarak Makecha, a former Tesla employee, who created the list without consulting program managers at the department's Office of Justice Programs. Bondi said the cuts reflected the priorities of Trump. DOJ grants typically run for 3 years and grant focuses often change from admin to admin, however, grants are rarely cut outright. A day after some Reuters reported on the cuts, seven of them were restored including for a program for pet-friendly domestic violence shelters. One terminated grant that wasn't restored was $8.3 million to the National Policing Institute, which funded rural police departments and district attorneys' offices to help pay for automated license plate readers, violent crime investigators, investigations against drug dealers for fentanyl overdoses, and programs to combat child sexual abuse. Bondi later tweeted examples of "wasteful grants," including a $2 million to "national listening sessions of individuals with lived experience," DOGE quote tweeted with "Great work." That $2 million grant trained prosecutors to investigate child abuse in juvenile detention facilities, youth correctional facilities or group homes; the listening sessions allowed prosecutors to hear directly from youth abuse victims. [1] [2] [3]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Reforming The Federal Hiring Process And Restoring Merit To Government Service
  • Orders the Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy, OBM, OPM, and DOGE to develop a "Federal Hiring Plan that brings to the Federal workforce only highly skilled Americans." The plan should hire only based on passion for the US, no racial or sexual hiring. [1]
  • On Jan 29th, the White House offered 2 million federal full-time employees financial incentives to quit in a "deferred resignation program" to further shrink the government. The offer went to all employees except those in immigration, national security, or the US Postal Service, and warned that a majority of agencies are likely to be downsized through restructurings and layoffs and that their jobs were not guaranteed. By the following week, it was reported that 20,000 federal employees had already taken the offer. Following the Reagan airport plane crash, Trump exempted air traffic controllers and federal employees involved in public safety programs from the resignation offer incentives, the exemption came after ATCs already had received early retirement offers. The TSA also said their 65,000 workforce was exempt from the offer. On Feb 5, 2025, the CIA offered buyouts to its entire workforce, citing that it wanted to bring the agency in line with Trump's EO. The Office of the Director of National Intelligence, National Security Agency, National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency and the National Reconnaissance Office were also offered buyouts in addition to the CIA. [3] [4] [5] [6] [8]
  • On Feb 4, 2025, American Federation of Government Employees and two other unions sued Trump for its plan to buyout federal workers, claiming the buyout offer is "arbitrary and capricious" and violates federal law, alleging that the admin cannot guarantee the plan will be funded and has failed to consider the consequences of mass resignations. On Feb 6, 2025, a Boston US District judge temporarily blocked Trumps's buyout until 2/10/25 (which was extended until a long term ruling could be made) in ruling on the union's lawsuit, the judge's ruling came hours before the buyout deadline. The ruling came even despite there already having been 60,000 federal employees who accepted the offer, out of 2.3 million total federal employees. [2] [7] [9]
  • On Feb 12, 2025, a Boston district judge ruled that the Trump admin could go ahead with their buyout offer, saying the unions that were suing him had no legal standing to bring the case. However, the end date for the offer had already passed, with only 75,000 workers taking it (70,000 normally retire a year) [10]
  • Also on Feb 12, 2025, 5 unions sued Trump in a Washington DC federal court, alleging that Trump's buyout plan was unconstitutional under the separation of powers. The unions included the United Auto Workers, the National Treasury Employees Union, the National Federation of Federal Employees, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, and the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers. [11]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 141 Designating Cartels And Other Organizations As Foreign Terrorist Organizations And Specially Designated Global Terrorists
  • Executive Order: Declares a immigration national emergency to deal with the Tren de Aragua (TdA) and La Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) cartel gangs. Orders the Secretary of State to take action to designate any cartel as "Specially Designated Global Terrorists" The order also utilized a 1798 law called the Alien Enemies Act against foreign gang members. [1] [2]
  • TgA designated as terrorist org: On Feb 19, 2025, the Trump admin designated Tren de Aragua, the Sinaloa Cartel and other drug cartels as global terrorist organizations. The designations aim to disrupt cartel finances through sanctions, including asset freezes and travel bans. [3]
  • TgA terrorism arrests: On April 23, 2025, the DOJ charged an alleged high ranking member of TgA with terrorism charges, the first time the US has made such charges against the street gang. The man's name was Jose Enrique Martinez Flores and was charged in a new indictment with conspiring to provide and providing material support to a foreign terrorist organization. [1]
    • 1/20/2025 EO 14172 Restoring Names That Honor American Greatness
  • Renamed the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America and Denali to Mount McKinley. Denali means 'tall' in the Koyukon Indigenous language and was changed from Mount McKinley in 1975 at Alaska's request. [1] [2]
  • Trump later named February 9th as "Gulf of America Day." [3]
  • On Feb 12, 2025, Trump barred AP reporters from accessing the Oval Office, where Trump had given almost daily addresses to the press. Trump refused to let the AP in because they continued to use the term "Gulf of Mexico" instead of "Gulf of America." AP, citing editorial standards, said it would continue to use the gulf's established name. Most news organizations, including Reuters, continued to call the body of water the Gulf of Mexico but were not barred like AP. On Feb 19, 2025, Trump permanently barred AP reporters from accessing the Oval Office and Air Force One, until the news agency stops referring to the Gulf of Mexico. [4] [5]
  • On Feb 21, 2025, the AP sued the Trump admin over their decision to restrict them from the WH, citing a First Amendment violation. On Feb 24, 2025, District Judge Trevor McFadden declined AP's request to issue an immediate TRO on Trump's banning of them from the Oval Office. On April 8, 2025, McFadden ruled that Trump must allow the AP back into the Oval Office and Air Force One, citing the First Amendment. McFadden said that Trump had unlawfully retaliated again the AP for their reporting. In April 16, 2025, the AP accused Trump of violating the order by continuing to restrict their access to the press pool when they restricted all wire services from the press pool. [1] [2] [3] [4]
  • At Trump's first cabinet meeting on Feb 26, 2025, the WH barred Reuters, the AP, HuffPost, and the German newspaper Der Tagesspiegel. They allowed ABC, Newsmax, Axios, the Blaze, Bloomberg News and NPR to cover the event. A group of D.C.-based journalists called the White House Correspondents' Association (WHCA) had traditionally rotated a pool of news organizations allowed to small space events, but the three wire services, AP, Bloomberg and Reuters, were always permanent members. WHCA issued a statement protesting the decision consolidate press coverage power under the WH allowing Trump to choose who will cover him. [1] [2]
  • On April 15, 2025, Trump removed Bloomberg, Reuters, and the AP from their permanent slot in the WH press pool. The pool typically has 10 outlets, that follow the President wherever he goes but Trump is changing it to 30 rotating outlets determined by Karoline Leavitt. The three wire services were permanent slot holders due to local news outlets relying on their reporting, due to these local outlets not having a presence in Washington. The AP had previously been revomed from the pool due to the Gulf of America spat. [1]
    • 1/21/2025 EO 14173 Ending Illegal Discrimination And Restoring Merit-Based Opportunity Terminated all DEI and affirmative action programs in the executive departments and start enforcing the termination of these programs in the private secotor. Rescinded orders 12898, 13583, 13672, 11246, and 13279. 11246 was originally put in place by LBJ in 1964, forbidding employment discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion and national origin by organizations receiving federal contracting and required federal contractors to set up "affirmative action" programs. Trump later sent out a memo that all federal DEI staff were places on paid leave. [1] [2] [1]
    1/22/2025 EO 14175 Designation Of Ansar Allah as a Foreign Terrorist Organization
  • Designated Ansar Allah, also called the Houthis, as a Foreign Terrorist Organization under the Immigration and Nationality Act. [1]
    • 1/23/2025 EO 14176 Declassification of Records Concerning the Assassinations of President John F. Kennedy, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, and the Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
  • Executive Order: Releases all remaining records related to the assassinations of JFK, RFK, and MLK. Several million records related to the assassinations has already been released, with this order releasing the final few thousand. Under Biden 13,000 JFK records had been declassified. During Trump's first term he promised to declassify the rest of the documents but didn't due to national security reasons by the CIA and FBI. [1] [2]
  • Releases: On Mar 18, 2025, Trump released over 80,000 documents related to the JFK assassination. On April 18, 2025, the National Arcives released 10,000 pages related to the Robert F. Kennedy assassination. [1] [2]
    • 1/23/2025 EO 14173 Strengthening American Leadership in Digital Financial Technology
  • Executive Order: Revokes Biden executive order 14067 and Department of the Treasury Framework of July 7, 2022 which set to regulate digital markets to protect investors and crack down on digital crime. Establishes the President's Working Group on Digital Asset Markets in the National Economic Council. The working group's job is to find all anti-crypto regulations so Trump can rescind them. Trump made venture capitalist and former PayPal exec David Sacks as the leader of the workgroup. The work group will also investigate establishing a national crypto stockpile. The order also protects equal access to banking services, alluding to the claims that crypto companies were cut off from banking services under the direction of US regulators, which the regulators have denied. The order also prohibits Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs). The order followed an announcement by the SEC that they were creating a task force to overhaul crypto policy. [1] [1] [3]
  • World Liberty Financial: Trump previously launched the World Liberty Financial Defi crypto project in fall 2024. By March 2025, and largely after his Nov 2024 election win, WLF had raised $550 million selling so-called governance tokens that cannot be traded, after only selling $2.7 million at launch in Oct 2024. Also as of Mar 2025, WLF was still yet to launch a Defi platform as first stated. Overall, the Trump family has a claim on 75% of net revenues from token sales and 60% from World Liberty operations once the core business gets going. WLF raised questions of conflicts of intrest, since Trump is in charge of crypto regulation. Wallet transactions show that 50% of purchases of $WLFI were for $1 million or more, with most of them purchases being anonymous, meaning they could be oligarcs trying to buy political influence by funnelling money to Trump. Trump and his wife Melania also each launched their own memecoins, $TRUMP and $MELANIA, after the election win. [1]
  • Justin Sun: On Feb 26, 2025, the SEC put Justin Sun's case on hold. Sun was a crypto entrepreneur who illegally generated $31 million while running the Tron network and BitTorrent. Sun had recently been a prominent buyer of Trump's World Liberty Financial token, buying $75 million of the token, including a $30 mln purchase of $WLFI to jumpstart the project. On Feb 28, 2025, a federal judge dismissed an SEC case against Hex founder Richard Heart, saying that the deceptive transactions that Heart directed were conducted on international markets not US ones. [1] [2]
  • Strategic Crypto Reserve: On Mar 2, 2025, Trump said he directed the work group to form a strategic crypto reserve that included XRP, SOL, and ADA, each rose between 10-35% after the announcement. Trump later said BTC and ETH would also "obviously" be included in the reserve, spirking their prices by 11-13%. [1]
  • Hawk Tuah girl: On Mar 29, 2025, the SEC cleared Hailey Welch (Hawk Tuah Girl) of any charges in her $HAWK token investigation. $HAWK previously hit a $490M market cap before crashing by 95% in minutes. The SEC clarified that meme coins do not qualify as securities, so they could not prosecute her. [1]
  • Crypto enforcement ended: On April 8, 2025, the DOJ disbanded its National Cryptocurrency Enforcement Team and told them to focus on only crypto use in terrorism/cartels. [1]
  • Nexo capital: In 2023, Nexo left the US after agreeing to pay $45 million in penalties to settle charges from the SEC and state regulators. On April 28, 2025, Nexo announced they were returning to US markets while hosting Trump Jr at a conference in Bulgaria. [1]
  • $TRUMP coin: In May 2025, Trump offered the top 220 of his $TRUMP meme coin to dine with him in his DC country club. The largest holder of $TRUMP coin is Justin Sun. At the time of the announcement, $TRUMP had a $2.74 billion market cap, with Trump's family company and a second firm together holding 80% of the remaining supply of the meme coins. Trump has so far (as of May 2025) made $320.19 million in fees from the meme coin, including at least $1.35 million after the dinner announcement. At least two of the largest investors in the $TRUMP contest have made profits in excess of $10 million each, while 15 investors have made more than $1 million. Meanwhile, about 600,000 other wallets have lost $3.87 billion so far, with $117 million of losses occurring after Trump announced the dinner on social media [1]
    • 1/23/2025 EO 14175 President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology Establishes the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (PCAST). Made up of 24 members including the Assistant to the President for Science and Technology (APST) and the Special Advisor for AI & Crypto, and the rest being members from the private sector. The council is responsible for advising the president on matters involving science, technology, education, and innovation policy.
