The reforms include to hiring practices and the removal of procedures. [1] [2]
    • 2/13/2025 EO 14212 Establishing the President's Make America Healthy Again Commission
  • Executive Order: Orders all federally funded research to be open source and not have conflicts of interest. Orders the NIH to identify the root cause of why so many American's are getting sick. Orders agencies to work with farmers to ensure US food is the healthiest, most abundant, and most affordable in the world. Orders agencies to allow expanded treatment options (like Ivermectin) and make these options covered by health insurance. Establishes the Make America Healthy Again Commission chaired by the Secretary of the HHS (RFK Jr). The mission of the commission is to advise Trump on addressing "the childhood chronic disease crisis." The commission must submit a "Make our Children Healthy Again Assessment" to Trump within 100 days that assesses childhood chronic disease in America. The assessment includes looking at medications, certain food ingredients, SSRI usage, physical activity, mental health. Orders the commission to submit within 180 days to Trump a "Make our Children Healthy Again Strategy" to implement the findings from the assessment. [1]
  • RFK Jr: After the EO, Kennedy vowed to open up its data, conduct new scientific studies on vaccines and tackle gaps in rural healthcare with artificial intelligence and telemedicine. He said he also planned to go after food additives, which are regulated by the FDA. Kennedy also said he plans to review of the safety of abortion drug mifepristone after Trump ordered him to, which was a policy proposal from Project 2025. However, Kennedy and his ambissions from the MAHA commission are in direct opposition to Trump's proposed downsizing of the federal workforce. [3] [4]
  • Flouride in water: One issue that RFK Jr called for the end to in the past is fluoride in water, which occurs naturally in some water and can prevent tooth decay. After fluoride began to be added to the US water supply in the 1940s, the US saw a massive decline in tooth decay (60% decrease among school children). Water fluoridation is typically done at the state and local level and is not mandated federally. However, the NIH conducted a meta-analysis that showed IQ was lower in children with high fluoride exposure. Cochrane also did a meta-analysis and found that including fluoride in water only has modest benefits in reducing tooth decay. [2]
  • ACIP Postponed: On Feb 20, 2025, RFK Jr postponed the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), a group that meets multiple times a year to review and make recommendations to the CDC on vaccines. The ACIP meeting was later rescheduled for April 2025. On Feb 27, 2025, the FDA also canceled a Vaccine and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee meeting to discuss the influenza vaccine. [1] [2] [3]
  • Funding freeze for CRTs: On Feb 10, 2025, a US District judge, Angel Kelley, issued a TRO on the Trump admin from freezing funding to the NIH for labs and clinical trials. The order was later extended while the case was decided. The NIH had previously sharply reduced the rate at which it reimbursed research institutions for "indirect costs" (like lab space, faculty, equipment and infrastructure), which Trump capped at 15% from 27%-28%. On Mar 6, 2025, Kelley made a final ruling, issuing a nationwide block on the cutting of the NIH reaearch funding, saying they were unlawful. [6] [2]
  • Measles ourbreak: In late Feb 2025, there was a a measles outbreak of 500 people in Texas and New Mexico, with the first child dying of measles since 2015 also (second child later died in April 2025 in same outbreak). Kennedy said the child who died in April died from "a bacteriological infection" but not measles, a common anti-vax tactic, despite Texas health officials saying measles was the cause. Kennedy responded by saying outbreaks were not "unusual" and that there were 16 in 2024, rather than emphasizing the need for vaccination, Kennedy later went on to endorse the vaccine as the best way to prevent measles while still advocating for alt-treatments as well. The alternative treatments included Vitamin A (only works for malnurished kids), steroid budesonide (risky due to immune system suppression), and the antibiotic clarithromycin (antibiotics cannot treat viral infections). Public health experts called for the Trump admin to encourage vaccines at the national level due to almost all (97%) the children being admitted to the hospital during the outbreak being unvaccinated, with some using Vitamin A instead due to advice from Kennedy's Children's Health Defense. Kennedy also said patients were only being held at the hospital to quarantine, but Texas hospital officials said they were not and the patients had serious respiratory issues. Despite the outbreak, on Mar 11, 2025, RFK Jr went on Hannity and said the MMR vaccine causes "deaths every year," despite there being no recorded deaths from the MMR vaccine in healthy, non-immunocompromised people. Later in April 2025, RFK Jr said that measles is always going to be around since the MMR vaccine wanes quickly, despite the MMR vaccine having 97% lifetime effectiveness after 2 doses. In 1963 before the vaccine there were 3-4 million measles cases a year, not it is usually fewer than 200 in a normal year. High vaccination rates are important because when 95% of people are vaccinated then the community has herd immunity, which protects people who are too young or who cannot get the vaccine due to health issues. On May 1, 2025, Kennedy also said that the MMR vaccines contain aborted fetal debris (which they do not, rubella vaccine was first produced from a fetal cell line in the 1960s) and that the mumps vaccine didn't work (despite having 86% effectivness). [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8]
  • USDA food inspection cuts: On Mar 7, 2025, the USDA eliminated the National Advisory Committee on Microbiological Criteria for Foods and the National Advisory Committee on Meat and Poultry Inspection. The move was part of Trumps broader effort to reduce the size of the government. [1]
  • Elimination of the self-affirm provision: On Mar 10, 2025, Kennedy eliminated an FDA provision that allows companies to self-affirm that food ingredients are safe. Before, the FDA strongly encouraged manufacturers to submit notices under a rule known as Substances Generally Recognized as Safe, but they could also self-affirm the use of a substance without notifying the FDA. [1]
  • Cutting of COVID grants: On Mar 26, 2025, the HHS cancelled $12 bln in federal grants to states from COVID. The grants included funding to track, prevent and control infectious diseases, including measles and bird flu, as well as track mental health services and fund addiction treatment. On April 3, 2025, US District Judge Mary S. McElroy in Rhode Island issued a TRO blocking Trump from cutting the HHS funding. On May 6, 2025, US District Judge Edgardo Ramos issued a preliminary injunction blocking Trump from canceling more than $1.1 billion in unspent aid meant to help U.S. elementary and high schools address the long-term effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. [1] [2] [3]
  • Peter Marks fired: On Mar 29, 2025, the FDA's top vaccine official, Peter Marks, was forced to resign by HHS officials. In his resignation letter, Marks wrote, "It has become clear that truth and transparency are not desired by the Secretary, but rather he wishes subservient confirmation of his misinformation and lies." Marks' resignation came after Kennedy requested that Marks turn over data on cases of brain swelling and deaths caused by the measles vaccine, which Marks said is data that doesn't exist. Marks was temporarily replaced by FDA insider Scott Steele, a WH adviser on science and technology during Bush 43. On May 6, 2025, Marks was succeeded by Vinay Prasad, a noted COVID vaccine mandates, and FDA leadership critic. [1] [2] [3]
  • Planned Parenthood cuts: On Mar 31, 2025, the HHS cut $27.5 mln in federal funding from Title X for Planned Parenthood for family planning inlcuding birth control, cancer screenings and other services for low-income people. [1] [2]
  • FDA cuts and changes: As part of DOGE cuts, the FDA fired 3500 staff. This included 15 senior FDA negotiators in talks with the pharmaceutical industry over renewing the user fee programs that fund the FDA's drug review system (70% of funding comes from these industry fees). However, on May 2, 2025, 10 of the negotiating staff were asked to return from being fired. The cuts also included the FDA quality control program for its food testing laboratories, affecting lab testing for the parasite Cyclospora in spinach or the pesticide glyphosate in barley. The cuts also included the Interlaboratory Comparison Exercise for detecting Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza program, which was an effort to improve its bird flu testing of milk, cheese and pet food. On April 17, 2025, the FDA announced they would limit employees from pharma companies regulated by the FDA from serving on the FDA's advisory committees to reduce conflicts of intrest. On April 21, 2025, the FDA suspended its proficiency testing program for Grade "A" (or fluid milk, meets the highest sanitary standards) raw milk and finished products due to staffing shortages. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6]
  • Autism: RFK Jr has claimed that autism is an "epidemic" and that we know that it is caused by "environmental exposure." The autism rate in 8 year olds in the US was 3.2% (1 in 31) in 2022, up from 0.66% in 2000. Research suggests 80% of autism risk is genetic, including Fragile X syndrome, tuberous sclerosis complex, Phelan-McDermid syndrome, and Prader-Willi syndrome. In the late 1990s, British researcher Andrew Wakefield published a since-debunked study linking measles vaccines to higher autism rates, RFK Jr has since promoted the theory that vaccines cause autism. No rigorous studies have found links between autism and vaccines or their components such as thimerosal or formaldehyde. Also, vaccination rates have declined as autism rates have climbed. Researchers largely attribute the rise in autism diagnoses to more widespread screening and the inclusion of a wider range of behaviors to describe the condition. Historically, the definition of autism included moderate to severe intellectual disabilities but today the most severe forms account for only about 25% of cases. [1] [2]
  • Food Dyes: On April 22, 2025, the FDA announced they would begin removing food dyes from the US food supply by revoking authorization for 2 dyes and working with the private sector to remove 6 others. They cited concerns about a possible link between consumption of the dyes and health conditions like ADHD, obesity and diabetes. The FDA said they also planned to authorize 4 new natural color additives (in May 2025 they approved 3 natural dyes). At the April 2025 cabinet meeting, RFK Jr said food dyes "affects academic performance, violence in the schools, and mental health, as well as physical health." Research shows synthetic food colors common in the U.S. are linked to neurobehavioral problems in children and may cause or exacerbate symptoms, particularly hyperactivity. However, there is no clear evidence of a direct relationship between food dyes and academic performance, violence or other mental and physical conditions. [1] [2] [3]
  • Novavax approval: In April 2025, the FDA delayed the approval of the Novavax COVID vaccine, saying it would only get approved if the company agrees to provide additional clinical data on effectiveness after the approval. Novavax is not an mRNA vaccine and is the only alternative to mRNA vaccines for many people. RFK Jr said that the Novavax shot targets only one antigen or part of the virus to produce an immune response and "single-antigen vaccines have never worked for respiratory illnesses." This is not true, as all of the first-generation COVID-19 vaccines were single-antigen vaccines. [1]
  • DOJ cuts: On April 25, 2025, the DOJ disbanded their U.S. food and drug safety laws enforcement unit. The Consumer Protection Branch is an unusual office because its work involves a hybrid of criminal prosecutions and civil enforcement. The CPB previously brought high profile cases against Walgreens, who agreed to pay $350 million for illegally filling unlawful opioid prescriptions and filing false claims to the government, and against the Peanut Corporation for crimes that led to a 2009 outbreak involving more than 700 cases of salmonella poisoning. [1]
  • Bird Flu cuts: On April 29, 2025, the CDC canceled a workshop on preventing human bird flu infections due to a contract termination, farmers had requested the workshop because suboptimal use of PPE contributed to earlier farmworker cases. The workshop was expected to discuss best practices for the use of personal protective equipment for people at heightened risk of bird flu, like farmworkers and veterinarians. [1]
  • Universal vaccine: On May 1, 2025, the HHS announced $500 million in funding to develop a universal vaccine technology to target multiple strains of different viruses such as influenza and coronaviruses. They said flu vaccines are expected by 2026 and an FDA decision by 2029. [1]
  • NIH cuts: Between Feb-April 2025, the NIH cut $1.8 billion in medical research funding. The cuts included $506 million for the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and $224 million for the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities. [1]
    • 2/14/2025 EO 14XXX Establishing the National Energy Dominance Council
  • Establishes the National Energy Dominance Council within the Executive Office of the President. The Secretary of the Interior is to lead the council. The council's function is to advise Trump on how to "produce more energy to make America energy dominant," by cutting bureaucratic red tape. They will also produce a National Energy Dominance Strategy for Trump. [1]
  • Before the order, the US was already at record-setting oil and gas production. Trump also announced he granted conditional export authorization for a huge liquefied natural gas project in Louisiana, Biden had paused new LNG exports in 2024. Trump also directed Burgum to undo Biden's ban on future offshore oil drilling. [2]
  • After the order was signed, the Trump admin assigned the DOJ to assist the EPA in rescinding $20 billion in grants awarded under Biden for climate and clean energy projects. In connection with this, Trump asked the head of the criminal division at the AG's office, Denise Cheung, to open a criminal grand-jury investigation for wire fraud and conspiracy into one of these contracts awarded under Biden. Cheung refused to open the investigation, citing lack of evidence, upon which she was ordered instead to pursue an asset seizure to prevent the recipient of the contract from getting funding. Cheung consulted with the FBI before deciding to recommend a "30-day administrative freeze on certain assets," which the Trump admin told her was no adequate and again demanded a full freeze and asked her to resign. On Feb 18, 2025, Cheung announced her resignation after 24 years with the DOJ. [3] [4]
    • 2/15/2025 EO 14XXX Keeping Education Accessible and Ending Covid-19 Vaccine Mandates in Schools
  • Directs the Secretary of Education to made Trump a plan on how to end the "coercive COVID-19 school mandates." The plan includes a list of Federal funding that can be witheld from elementary schools, local educational agencies, State educational agencies, secondary schools, and institutions of higher education if they still have COVID-19 vaccine mandates. [1]
  • The EO was mostly symbolic as most COVID-19 vaccine mandates have been dropped by schools and colleges in the US. Trump had made a promise on the campaign trail that he "would ot give one penny to any school that has a vaccine mandate." All US states currectly have laws mandating children in schools be vaccinated from measles, mumps, polio, tetanus, whooping cough and chickenpox, with excemptions if they are unable due to medical conditions. [2]
    • 2/18/2025 EO 14XXX Expanding Access to In Vitro Fertilization
  • Orders the Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy to submit a list of policy recommendations to Trump on protecting IVF access and bringing down the cost of IVF within 90 days. [1]
  • Bofore the order was signed, most states didn't require insurers to cover IVF. IVF is combinging eggs and sperm in a labratory dish to create an embryo for couples who have trouble conceiving, the coverage can cost thousand of dollars. IVF became a controversial issue after the Alabama supreme court ruled in 2024 that embryos were children, which left it unclear how to treat IVF embryos. [2]
    • 2/18/2025 EO 14XXX Ensuring Accountability for All Agencies
  • Directs the head of the OMB to set performance standards and management objectives for agency heads. Directs the OMB head to regularly review independed agancies for consistency with Trump's policies, and withold funding if they are not in line with Trump's agenda. Establishes a White House Liaison in each agency to regularly consult with Trump. Says Trump and the AG are the only ones who can "provide authoritative interpretations of law for the executive branch." [1]
  • The order gives more control to Trump over independent agencies like the SEC, FTC, NLRB, and FCC. The order does not include the Federal Reserve FOMC. Traditionally, these agencies have been independent from the president to avoid being politically pressured during their missions. Prior administrations allowed independent agencies to work without political interference, this order allows Trump to exert more political influence on independent agencies by having a political representative in each agency. [2] [3]
  • The same day, Trump Truthed "LONG LIVE THE KING!" with respect to his administration's decision to rescind federal approval of New York City's traffic congestion pricing program. The WH also tweeted a fake magazine cover of Trump in a crown. [3]
  • This EO flew in the face on a unanimous 1935 Supreme Court decision known as Humphrey's Executor, as Trump aimed to continue his "unitary executive theory." Humphrey's Executor says that the president cannot fire appointed leaders of federal agencies without cause. However, unitary executive theorists say that the president should be able to fire agency heads at will, saying he has the power through the constitution. William Humphrey an FTC chair and FDR tried to fire him in 1933 to put someone new who agreed with the New Deal. Humphrey refused but died a year later, but the Supreme Court ruled that the person administering his estate (Humphrey's executor) was entitled to his back pay since the law establishing the FTC was constitutional and that FDR's action was improper. [5]
  • On Feb 28, 2025, the Dem Party sued Trump over the EO, saying his order violated federal election laws by giving him too much power over the Federal Election Commission (FEC). [1]
    • 2/19/2025 EO 14XXX Commencing the Reduction of the Federal Bureaucracy
  • Directs the following to be eliminated to the maximum extent allowed statutorily: the Presidio Trust, the Inter-American Foundation, the US African Development Foundation, Revokes Presidential Memorandum of November 13, 1961 (Need for Greater Coordination of Regional and Field Activities of the Government). Directs the OPM to terminate regulations at title 5, part 362, subpart D, Code of Federal Regulations and the terminate the Presidential Management Fellows Program. Directs USAID to terminate the Advisory Committee on Voluntary Foreign Aid. Directs the CFPB to terminate the Academic Research Council and the Credit Union Advisory Council. Directs the FDIC to terminate the Community Bank Advisory Council. Directs the HHS to terminate the Advisory Committee on Long COVID. Directs Medicare and Medicaid to terminate the Health Equity Advisory Committee. [1]
    • 2/19/2025 EO 14XXX Ensuring Lawful Governance and Implementing the President's "Department of Government Efficiency" Deregulatory Initiative
  • Directs all agencies to work with DOGE to terminate all regulations that are unconstitutional, unlawful, uncostly, or burden small businesses within 60 days. Regulations that should be ended due to the order are ones that the Trump admin considers "overreach." Directs agencies to only enforce regulations that align with Trump policies. Directs all agancies to go through DOGE first if they want to create any new regulations. Exempts anything related to the OMB, military, national security, homeland security, foreign affairs, or immigration-related functions. [1] [3]
  • On Feb 19, 2025, DOGE said it had saved $55 bln in federal spending so far. However, they were only able to site 1100 canceled contracts and 100 canceled leases so far, amounting to $8.5 bln, with the other $46 bln unaccounted for. Of the $8.5 bln, DOGE said $6.5 bln was from USAID, $501 mln from the Dept of Education, and $232 mln from Social Security. One of the contracts, DOGE said saved $8 bln, when it turned out to only be $8 mln. [2]
    • 2/19/2025 EO 14XXX Ending Taxpayer Subsidization of Open Borders
  • Executive Order: Cites the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (Public Law 104-193) (PRWORA), saying illegal aliens cannot obtain taxpayer-funded benefits. Directs the head of each agency to terminate any federal funding that might be going to illegal aliens. Withholds federal funding from states who "facilitate the subsidization or promotion of illegal immigration" or sanctuary cities. [1]
  • Immigrant Benefits: Illegal aliens generally do not qualify for federal benefits except for emergency medical care. Under a 1982 Supreme Court ruling, all children regardless of immigration status are entitled to a free K-12 education. The order aimed to target a Biden policy of using the parole authority to temporarily allow illegal immigrants into the US including 900,000 from the Mexico border, 500,000 Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans and Venezuelans who flew, and 300,000 from Ukraine and Afghanistan. Those granted parole for at least a year are "qualified non-citizens," making them eligible for Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program (child coverage if you make too much for Medicaid), but only after 5 years [2]
  • Social Security Memo: On April 15, 2025, Trump signed a presidential memo to prevent undocumented immigrants from receiving Social Security benefits. Some undocumented workers obtain jobs by using fake or borrowed Social Security numbers and pay into Social Security, but are not eligible to receive social security benefits under current law. [1] [2]
  • Sanctruary cities lawsuit: On April 24, 2025, US District Judge William Orrick in San Fran issued a preliminary injunction at the request of request of 16 sanctuary cities and counties nationally In the ruling Orrick said that Trump's order likely unconstitutionally imposed conditions on federal funding without congressional authorization and ran afoul of the localities' due process rights. The cities all have laws and policies that limit or prevent local law enforcement from assisting federal officers with civil immigration arrests. Orrick previously ruled against a similar EO from Trump's first term, the ruling was upheld in an appeals court. [1]
    • 2/25/2025 EO 14220 Addressing the Threat to National Security from Imports of Copper
  • Directs the Secretary of Commerce Howard Lutnick to investigate under section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act to determine the national security impacts of copper imports. The investigation should be reported with any policy recommendations to Trump within 270 days. [1]
  • The order opens the door for Trump to issue new tariffs on copper. During his first term, Trump used Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act to impose 25% global tariffs on steel and aluminum. The WH said they were targeting China with the order, saying it was using state subsidies and excess capacity to undermine competition and gain control over global copper production. Chile, Canada and Mexico, which were the top suppliers of copper in 2024. [1]
    • 2/25/2025 EO 14221 Making America Healthy Again by Empowering Patients with Clear, Accurate, and Actionable Healthcare Pricing Information
  • Directs the Treasury, Dept of Labor, and HHS, within 90 days, to implement Trumps previous EO 13877 (Improving Price and Quality Transparency in American Healthcare to Put Patients First) from 2019. This includes requiring disclosure of actual prices of medications no estimates and issuing guidance on ensuring transparent drug price reporting. EO 13877 required health insurers and hospitals to disclose healthcare cost details. EO 13877 was strongly opposed by hospital groups who unsuccessfully challenged it in court in 2020. [1] [2]
  • In the order, Trump took aim at Biden, saying he failed to enforce EO 13877. However, online records show Biden took enforcement action against 18 hospitals between 2022-2025. [1]
    • 2/26/2025 EO 14222 Implementing the President's "Department of Government Efficiency" Cost Efficiency Initiative
  • Executive Order: Directs agency heads to work with their respective DOGE team lead to establish centralized technological systems in each agency. The systems would be used to record every payment that the agency makes, including contracts and grants, with a justification for each payment. The systems also were required to have a mechanism to allow agency heads to immediately halt payments. Orders each agency to work with DOGE to review, within 30 days, all existing contracts to terminate or modify them if they don't align with Trump policies or were for for "waste, fraud and abuse." Directs each agency to also work with DOGE to make a similar system to approve federally funded travel. Freezes all credit cards held by federal employees within 30 days. Directs all agencies to identify to the GSA any leases that can be terminated. [1] [2]
  • DOGE employees resign: On Feb 25, 2025, a day before the order, 21 DOGE employees resigned, saying they refused to use their technical expertise to "dismantle critical public services." The resignations included engineers, data scientists, designers and product managers who all had previously held senior tech roles at tech companies like Google and Amazon. The employees had previously worked for the US Digital Services and were perparing to be integrated into DOGE. [1] [2]
  • Staffing cuts order: At Trump's first cabinet meeting on Feb 26, 2025, Trump ordered federal agencies to submit plans by March 13 for a "significant reduction" in staffing. [1]
  • EPA to cut 65% of staff: At the cabinet meeting, Trump also said Lee Zeldin was going to cut 65% of the workforce from the EPA (has 15,000 employees), this was later walked back to say 65% of spending would be cut, not the workforce. Trump also said that the GSA was going to terminate 1,100 leases for office space by the end of the year. [1] [2]
  • USDA cuts food banks: On Mar 10, 2025, the USDA cut the $660 million Local Food for Schools program and the Local Food Purchase Assistance Cooperative Agreement Program, which would have funded about $500 million in 2025 to support food banks. The cuts further strained US food banks, which help fight hunger in the US, who had already been strained by inflation and COVID. [1] [2]
  • On April 30, 2025, the USDA said that new farm loans over $500,000 will require DOGE approval. Farmers who have trouble accessing credit normally go to the USDA for loans for operational expenses including seeds, fertilizers and pesticides, or to buy land. The USDA services about 8% to 10% of farms with loans. [1]
    • 3/1/2025 EO 14223 Designating English as the Official Language of The United States
  • Makes English the official language of the US. Revokes Bill Clinton EO 13166 that required the government and organizations that received federal funding to provide language assistance to non-English speakers. The order allows agancies to still provide documents and services in languages other than English however. Before the order, 20 US states already had English designated as its official language. Critics of the order say that designating only one official language could further marginalize minirities who don't speak English. [1] [2]
    • 3/1/2025 EO 14224 Immediate Expansion of American Timber Production
  • Directs within 30 days the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to issue guidance on increasing US timber production. Directs within 60 days the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Commerce to complete a strategy to improve the speed of approving forestry projects. Directs within 90 days the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to submit to Trump a plan setting a target annual amount of timber to be on sale from Federal lands for the next 4 years. Directs within 120 days the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to complete the Whitebark Pine Rangewide Programmatic Consultation. Directs within 180 days the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to reduce any lengthy processes or costs associated with timber production. Directs within 280 days the Secretary of the Interior establish a new categorical exclusion for timber thinning and re-establish a categorical exclusion for timber salvage activities. Directs all agencies to eliminate all "undue delays within their respective permitting processes related to timber production." Establishes a Endangered Species Committee to more quickly review endangered species submissions. [1]
  • The goal of the order is to streamline the permitting process by salvaging more wood from forests and expand how much wood product can be offered for sale, possibly lower housing and construction costs. A secondary goal was to help prevent wildfires and improve the habitat for animals. [1]
    • 3/1/2025 EO 14225 Addressing The Threat To National Security from Imports of Timber, Lumber
  • Directs the Secretary of Commerce to investigate, under section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act, to determine any harms to national security of imports of timber, lumber, and their derivative products. The Secretary of Commerce should sumbit a report with findings and recommendations to Trump within 270 days of the order. [1]
  • Trump officials had previously said that Canada, Brazil and Germany, among others, are engaged in subsidies regarding lumber that put the US at a disadvantage. [1]
    • 3/2/2025 EO 14226 Amendment to Duties to Address the Flow of Illicit Drugs across our Northern Border
  • Allows duty-free de minimis shipments to be exempt from the Canada tariffs until a system is in place to collect them. Duty-free de minimis is anything under $800 (like Amazon and Temu packages). [1]
    • 3/2/2025 EO 14227 Amendment to Duties to Address the Situation at our Southern Border
  • Allows duty-free de minimis shipments to be exempt from the Mexico tariffs until a system is in place to collect them. Duty-free de minimis is anything under $800 (like Amazon and Temu packages). [1]
    • 3/3/2025 EO 14228 Further Amendment to Duties Addressing th Synthetic Opioid Supply Chain in the People's Republic of China
  • Increases the China tariffs from EO 14195 from 10% to 20% due to them not complying with Trump's orders. [1]
  • China immediately responded to the increase with additional tariffs of 10%-15% on certain U.S. imports and a series of new export restrictions for designated U.S. entities. China's retaliatory tariffs target US agricultural products including certain meats, grains, cotton, fruit, vegetables and dairy products. Their export restrictions included 25 U.S. firms under export and investment restrictions on national security grounds. Best Buy, who gets many of their electronics from China and Mexico, told consumers to expect higher prices. [1]
    • 3/5/2025 EO 14229 Honoring Jocelyn Nungaray
  • Renames the "Anahuac National Wildlife Refuge" to the "Jocelyn Nungaray National Wildlife Refuge" [1]
  • Jocelyn Nungaray was a 12 year old girl killed in Houston in 2024 by 2 Venezualans who were in the US illegally. Prosecutors allege the two men kidnapped, sexually assaulted and strangled the girl before leaving her body in shallow water below a bridge. Both men were arrested near El Paso by the USBP after entering the country without documentation but were released and given notices to appear in court at a later date. [1]
    • 3/6/2025 EO 14230 Amendment to the Duties to Address the Flow of Illicit Drugs Across out Northern Border
  • Changes the 25% tariff to only 10% for potash (fertilizer) coming from Canada. Also suspends the tariffs for goods for a month if they were part of the USMCA, which is most goods traded between the countries. [1]
  • On March 5, 2025, the WH allowed North American-built vehicles to be exempt for one month if they already followed complex rules of the 2020 U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement's. The reversal came after Trump met with many US automaker CEOs who pled with them for a lifeline. [1]
  • On Mar 6, 2025, Canada says they were pausing their tariffs on the US due to Trump's amendment. [1]
  • On Mar 11, 2025, Trump met with about 100 CEOs from the top US companies including Apple, JP Morgan Chase, and Walmart. The meeting came after a massive stock market selloff, with the S&P dropping 5.3% since the start of 2025. During the meeting, Trump defiantly maintained his stance, dismissed market volatility and vowed that investors would see gains for putting money to work now. [1]
    • 3/6/2025 EO 14231 Addressing Risks from Perkins Coie LLP
  • Executive Order: Orders the suspension of any active security clearances held by individuals at Perkins Coie. Orders the OMB to terminate any government benefits being given to Perkins Coie. Orders all government contracts with Perkins Coie to be terminated. Orders DOJ investigations into any large law firms who engage in DEI. Blacklists former Perkins Coie employees from being employed by the US government. [1]
  • Perkins Coie: Trump previously made a similar order against lawfirm Covington & Burling, who assisted Jack Smith in the Trump cases. Perkins Coie and Covington are among nearly a dozen major U.S. law firms representing clients in lawsuits against the Trump administration, challenging executive actions related to immigration, transgender rights and other issues. Perkins Coie also previosuly worked for Hillary Clinton in 2016. [1]
  • Lawsuit against the EO: On Mar 12, 2025 US District Judge Beryl Howell issued a TRO, partially blocking Trump's EO against Perkins Coie. Howell said "I am sure many in the legal profession are watching in horror about what Perkins Coie is going through here." The TRO blocked that part of the EO that sought to prevent the firm from doing business with federal contractors and to deny its lawyers access to government officials and buildings. The order didn't apply to the revocation of security clearances. On May 2, 2025, Howell struck down Trump's order due to free speech and due process violations, saying "Settling personal vendettas by targeting a disliked business or individual for punitive government action is not a legitimate use of the powers of the U.S. government or an American President." [1] [2]
  • 500 law firms denounce the EO: On April 4, 2025, 500+ law firms signed a court brief denouncing Trump's Perkins Coie EO, however, many large lawfirms resuded to sign on. [1]
    • 3/6/2025 EO 14232 Amendment to the Duties to Address the Flow of Illicit Drugs Across out Southern Border
  • Changes the 25% tariff to only 10% for potash (fertilizer) coming from Mexico. Also suspends the tariffs for goods for a month if they were part of the USMCA, which is most goods traded between the countries. [1]
  • On March 5, 2025, the WH allowed North American-built vehicles to be exempt for one month if they already followed complex rules of the 2020 U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement's. The reversal came after Trump met with many US automaker CEOs who pled with them for a lifeline. [1]
    • 3/6/2025 EO 14233 Establishment of the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and United States Digital Asset Stockpile
  • Creates a "Strategic Bitcoin Reserve" that is composed of BTC held by the Department of the Treasury that was forfeited as part of criminal or civil asset forfeiture. Creates a similar "United States Digital Asset Stockpile" but for crypto other than BTC. Creates an office a manage the Bitcoin reserve and the crypto reverse. Directs the Treasury to strategize on ways to aquire new BTC. Directs each agency to hand over any crypto they have so it can go in the reserves. [1]
  • The EO was mainly symbolic, as it marks the first time Bitcoin is formally recognized as a reserve asset of the United States government. Crypto bros were initially disappointed in the order since the reserves would only consist of crypto that the government halready had. [1]
    • 3/7/2025 EO 14234 Establishing the White House Task Force on the FIFA World Cup 2026
  • Establishes a "White House Task Force on the FIFA World Cup 2026" to be led by Trump. The task force is to work with agencies to coordinate the 2026 World Cup in the US. World Cup will have 48 teams playing 104 matches. [1] [2]
    • 3/7/2025 EO 142 Restoring Public Service Loan Forgiveness
  • Orders the Dept of Education to revise the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program (PSLF) so that public service members who "engage in activities that have a substantial illegal purpose" do not get loan forgiveness. This includes: violating immigration laws, supporting terrorism including cartels, participating in trans "child abuse", DEI "discrimination", and allowing vandalism. [1]
  • The PSLF was created in 2007 to encourage careers in the government or nonprofit groups by offering to cancel any remaining student debt after borrowers make 10 years of payments while working in public service. More than 2 mln Americans are eligible for the program as of Dec 2024. This Trump EO would disqualify workers of nonprofit groups deemed to have engaged in “improper” activities. [1]
    • 3/14/2025 EO 142/td> Additional Rescissions of Harmful Executive Orders and Actions
  • Revokes Biden EOs:
    • 13994 (Ensuring a Data-Driven Response to COVID-19 and Future High-Consequence Public Health Threats)
    • 14026 (Increasing the Minimum Wage for Federal Contractors)
    • 14081 (Advancing Biotechnology and Biomanufacturing Innovation for a Sustainable, Safe, and Secure American Bioeconomy)
    • 14112 (Reforming Federal Funding and Support for Tribal Nations to Better Embrace Our Trust Responsibilities and Promote the Next Era of Tribal Self-Determination)
    • 14119 (Scaling and Expanding the Use of Registered Apprenticeships in Industries and the Federal Government and Promoting Labor-Management Forums)
    • 14126 (Investing in America and Investing in American Workers)
    Also revokes a number of Biden Presidential Memorandums and Presidential Determinations. [1]
    • 3/14/2025 EO 142 Addressing Risks from Paul Weiss
  • Directs the ending of all security clearances for the Paul Weiss law firm. Directs the ending of all government work with Paul Weiss. Directs agencies to terminate any contracts they have with Paul Weiss. Directs agencies to limit all access of any Paul Weiss employees in government buildings. Blacklists any Paul Weiss employees from being allowed to work for the government. [1]
  • Some people associated with the Robert Mueller probe into Trump's ties to Russia during his first term were linked to Paul Weiss. Trump had been critical of a former partner at the firm, Mark Pomerantz, who was involved investigation into Trump's hush money payments to Stormy Daniels. Pomerantz left Paul Weiss in 2012. [1]
  • On Mar 19, 2025, Paul Weiss said that its client Steven Schwartz, former chief legal officer of Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp, had "terminated" the firm as its defense counsel due to Trump's EO. Schwartz was charged in 2019 and pleaded not guilty to violating the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in a bribery scheme in India. The Trump administration ordered a review of pending prosecutions under the foreign bribery law in EO 14209. According to a DOJ filing, Schwartz "is concerned that the firm's continued representation of him may negatively affect his ability to obtain a favorable review of his case." [1]
    • 3/14/2025 EO 142 Continuing the Reduction of the Federal Bureaucracy
  • Executive Order: Orders the elimination of all operations not codified in statute for:
    • the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service
    • the United States Agency for Global Media
    • the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in the Smithsonian Institution
    • the Institute of Museum and Library Services
    • the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness
    • the Community Development Financial Institutions Fund
    • the Minority Business Development Agency
    [1]
  • VOA: The day after the order, 1300 workers at Voice of America, an international media broadcaster that operates in more than 40 languages, were places on leave. Voice for America is under the he United States Agency for Global Media. Trump had previously made Kari Lake the head of VOA for his second term. On May 7, 2025, Lake announced that VOA would continue to provide newsfeed services but would contract the work out to the right-wing Trump-partisan OAN. The contracting came despite Lake previously saying VOA would be doing their news content following the cancellation of contracts with AP and Reuters. [1] [2]
  • Strengthening China: The dismantiling of US government-funded news outlets, including Voice of America and Radio Free Asia, were a blow to US soft-power, opening the door for China to strengthen their sphere of influence. Voice of America was originally made to combat Nazi propoganda during WW2. VOA now gives free press in authoritarian regimes including Russia and in Ukraine, while RFA gives free press in China and North Korea. China's Global Times tabloid rejoiced at VOA's closure, calling it a "lie factory." Cambodia's longtime authoritarian leader Hun Sen praised Trump's move to dismantle the news outlets, saying they were a "major contribution to eliminating fake news, disinformation, lies, distortions, incitement and chaos around the world." RFA had been a thorn in Beijing's side, with its Uyghur-speaking journalists helping to document what Rubio has called a "genocide" against the Muslim minority group. [1]
  • Agency for Global Media Lawsuits: On Mar 28, 2025, US District Judge J. Paul Oetken, ordered Trump temporarily pause the closing of VOA and that he could not fire the 1300 VOA journalists he had places on leave. Oetken said in the ruling that Congress approved and funded VOA so only they could dismantle it. On April 22, 2025, US District Judge Royce Lamberth ordered Trump to halt its efforts to shut down Voice of America, Radio Free Asia and Middle East Broadcasting Networks, saying he needed to restore the employees and contractors of the orgs due to their broadcasts being mandated by Congress. On April 29, 2025, Lamberth ordered Trump to restore $12 million in funding to Radio Free Europe, saying Congress having funding powers. Lamberth said Trump should not have signed the continuing resolution in Mar 2025 that included Global media funding if he wanted to cut it. On May 3, 2025, an appeals court ruled 2-1 to block Lamberth's order on VOA workers return and funding restore for Radio Free Asia, saying that Lamberth didn't have the jurisdiction. [1] [2] [3] [4]
  • Lawsuit against the EO: On May 6, 2025, US District Judge John McConnell in Providence, Rhode Island issued a PI blocking Trump's order from being implemented for the Institute of Museum and Library Services, the Minority Business Development Agency, and the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service pending the outcome of the case. The lawsuit stated that Congress created the agencies and set their funding levels, so Trump had no power to order that their work be halted. McConnell agreed, saying that federal law includes a mechanism for the president to return unneeded funding to Congress but Trump failed to follow that process. [1]
    • 3/19/2025 EO 142 Achieving Efficiency Through State and Local Preparedness
  • Policy of giving state and local governments the main role in national resilience and preparedness. Orders a National Resilience Strategy to be made within 90 days to advance US resilience. Orders the review of all critical infrastructure policies for revisions or recissions within 180 days (including Biden EOs 14017 and 14123). Orders the review of all national continuity policies for revisions or recissions within 180 days (including Biden EOs 13618, 13961, and 14146). Orders the review, with the help of the FEMA council from Trump EO 14180, of all national preparedness and response policies for revisions or recissions within 240 days (including Reagan EO 12656). Orders the creation of a National Risk Register that "identifies, articulates, and quantifies natural and malign risks to our national infrastructure, related systems, and their users," within 240 days. [1]
  • The EO was another step taken by Trump to weaken FEMA by shifting responsibility for disaster preparations to state and local governments. In the EO, Trump called for "common sense" investments by state and local governments to address risks like wildfires, hurricanes, and cyber attacks to enhance national security, but did not detail how they would be funded. [1]
    • 3/20/2025 EO 14242 Improving Education Outcomes by Empowering Parents, States, and Communities
  • Executive Order: Directs the Secretary of Education to begin taking steps to close the Dept of Education. Directs all DOE funding for DEI to be ended. [1]
  • US Depatrment of Education: Trump signed the order with a flank of students behind him in school desks. The order aimed to leave school policy almost entirely in the hands of states and local boards. Trump cannot dismantle the DOE without Congressional approval, which is unlikely. However, he has already promised to fire half the staff at the DOE, which would effectively shutter the department. According to a Rueters' poll, 65% of Americans oppose closing the DOE, with 30% in favor. [1]
  • Student Loans Transferred: On Mar 21, 2025, Trump said student loans programs would be transferred to the Small Business Administration and special needs and nutrition programs would be transferred to the HHS. Karoline Leavitt previously said student loans and Pell Grants would stay with the DOE. [1]
  • Defaulted Student Loans: On April 21, 2025, the Dept of Education said they will resume collecting federal student repayments from borrowers in default from May 5 after a pause of more than five years. Student loan collections were paused in 2020 as relief during COVID. At the time of the announcement, 5 million borrowers were in default and 4 million more were late on making payments. The DoE said that if defaulters cannot pay, they will have their wages garnished to pay for the loans. [1]
    • 3/20/2025 EO 142 Immediate Measures to Increase American Mineral Production
  • Executive Order: Orders the immediate approval of priority mineral projects within 10 days. Orders recommendations for the treatment of waste rock, tailings, and mine waste disposal under the Mining Act of 1872. Orders a list of all Federal lands known to hold mineral deposits and reserves so they can begin being developed. [1]
  • Critical Minerals: Lithium, nickel and other critical minerals are used in many electronics, including EV batteries. In 2024, China was the world's largets producer of these critical minerals, with the US alternatively producing very little. Also in 2024, Beijing imposed an outright ban on exports of gallium, germanium and antimony to the US. Trump used the 1950 Defense Production Act (DPA), used by Harry Truman for the Korean War, to invoke wartime powers in order to carry out the EO. Biden similarly used the DPA to carry out a similar program for critical minerals. Trump later named former Newmont executive David Copley has been named to oversee the mining portfolio for the U.S. National Energy Dominance Council. [1]
  • Rio Tinto copper mine: On May 9, 2025, US issued a TRO blocking Trump from transferring land to Rio Tinto and BHP for a copper mine opposed by the Apache Native Americans, until it could be heard by te Supreme Court. Trump started the land transfer in his first term, then Biden blocked it, then Trump recently started the transfer again in his second term. [1]
    • 3/20/2025 EO 14242 Eliminating Waste and Saving Taxpayer Dollars by Consolidating Procurement
  • Orders a proposal for the GSA to conduct domestic procurement within 60 days, then an order plan to the OMB 90 days later. [1]
  • This EO is to consolidate government procurement powers under only the GSA, rather than at specific agencies. [2]
    • 3/20/2025 EO 14243 Stopping Waste, Fraud, and Abuse by Eliminating Information Silos
  • Directs all agencies to eliminate any policies or guidances that are a barrier to the inter- or intra-agency sharing of unclassified information for the purposes related to the identification and elimination of waste, fraud, and abuse. Further orders agencies to review all classified information to see if it should really be classified. [1]
  • The EO allowed agencies to grant federal officials access to unclassified agency records, data and systems to stop waste and fraud. [1]
    • 3/21/2025 EO 14244 Addressing Remedial Action by Paul Weiss
  • Formally revoked EO 14237, informally did a day before. [1]
  • On Mar 20, 2025, Trump reversed the Paul Weiss EO, after Paul Weiss "acknowledged the wrongdoing" of an attorney who investigated Trump and also pledged $40 million in pro bono work for the government. Paul Weiss already performed $130 million in pro bono work annually. The move came after a meeting between the WH and Paul Weiss chairman, Brad Karp, who acknowledged the wrongdoing of Mark Pomerantz, a former partner at the New York firm, who was involved int Stormy Daniels case. Leslie Levin, a University of Connecticut law professor and expert on the legal profession, said Paul Weiss likely feared a client exodus from the EO since most of their work requires security clearance. After the deal between Trump and Paul Weiss, lawyers took to social media to criticise the firm for lacking courage and capitulating to Trump. karp later said that Trump would not dictate what pro bono work they would be doing as part of the deal. [1] [2] [3]
    • 3/24/2025 EO 14245 Imposing Tariffs on Countries Importing Venezuelan Oil
  • Imposed a 25% tariff on all goods coming into the US from any country that imports Venezualan oil. Tariffs will only be lifted 1 year after the country stops importing Venezualan oil. Cites Tren de Aragua and the Marudo regime as the reasoning. Tariffs start April 2, 2025. [1]
  • After the order, Trump extended the deadline to May 27 that he previously set to have Chevron stop operations in Venezuela. Trump also said the tariffs would apply to countries indirectly buying Venezuelan oil. Oil is Venezuela's main export, with China being the largest buyer with 503,000 barrels per day of Venezuelan crude and fuel, some 55% of total exports from Venezuela. India, Spain, Italy and Cuba also consume Venezuelan oil. The tariffs are likely to push China and India to just buy Russian oil instead. [1]
    • 3/25/2025 EO 14246 Modernizing Payments To and From America's Bank Account
  • Mandates the transission to electronic payments for all federal disbursements and receipts. Orders the Treasury to stop using paper checks by the end of Sept, 2025. Exeptions include: those without a bank account, emergency payments, national security risks. Agencies have 90 days to comply with this EO. [1]
  • The order was aimed at modernizing the Treasury payment system to minimize fraud and abuse. [1]
    • 3/25/2025 EO 14247 Protecting America's Bank Account Against Fraud, Waste, and Abuse
  • Orders all payments made by the Treasury for any agency must first be pre-certified to verify they are not fraud or abuse. Orders agencies to provide more data to the Treasury to ensure payments are not fraud or abuse. Says the government should not be paying the wrong people or paying dead people. Orders agencies to consolidate their core financial system within 180 days. Orders agencies to begin shutting down NTDOs (which can make their own payments, bypassing the Treasury). [1]
  • Payments will go through the General Fund in the Treasury. Aims to give the Treasury Department greater power and control to ensure these transactions are properly recorded and managed. Aims to ensure "traceability" of every transaction. In FY2024, NTDOs were estimated to be responsible for 181 million payments totaling more than $1.5 trillion. [1]
    • 3/25/2025 EO 14248 Preserving and Protecting the Integrity of our Elections
  • Executive Order: Prohibits foreign nationals from voting by requiring proof of US citizenship on their national mail voter registration. Directs the DHS and DOGE to work with states to find illegal voters. Makes Social Security info available to states to find illegal voters. Directs the witholding of funding to any state that doesn't comply with federal elections laws. Directs the AG to prioritize finding and prosecuting election fraud. [1]
  • Election Fraud in the US: Voting by non-citizens in the US is already illegal and rarely occurs. The EO comes after Trump complained for years of voter fraud in his election loss to Biden. With the EO, Trump showed he was done waiting for Congress to pass the SAVE Act, which would do the same thing as Trump's EO but be codified. The EO has the possibility of disenfranchising voters, with 9% of Americans (21 mln people) not having proof of citizenship readily available. The Constitution gives states authority to set the "times, places and manner" for elections, and gives Congress the power to regulate voting. [1] [2]
  • Lawsuit over election EO: On April 24, 2025, US District Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly in Washington partly blocked the election EO, saying that Trump overstepped his authority with new proof of citizenship, mail-in ballot rules (Congress oversees elections). She declined to block parts of the order that sought to force states not to count mail-in ballots received after election day. [1]
  • ActBlue memo: On April 24, 2025, Trump signed a memo to target Democratic fundraising group ActBlue and other online fundraising platforms, saying it aimed at cracking down on illegal foreign contributions in U.S. elections. The memo directed Bondi to investigate and prosecute ActBlue and the other fundraisers. It cites a congressional investigation that "revealed significant fraud schemes using ActBlue" as well as a 30-day period during the 2024 election when donations from foreign IPs using prepaid cards were detected. [1]
    • 3/25/2025 EO 14249 Addressing Risks from Jenner & Block
  • Suspends all security clearances for the Jenner & Block lawfirm. Blacklists Jenner & Block from contracting with the government. Blacklists Jenner & Block employees from entring government buildings or working in the government. [1]
  • Trump targeted Jenner and Block because they previously employed Andrew Weissmann, a top federal prosecutor involved in the Mueller investigation. Jenner & Block had also previously won court cases including one blocking Trump's EO halting gender treatment for those under 19 and another where he tried to curb asylum rights. Jenner & Block responded that the EO resembled one that "has already been declared unconstitutional" by a federal judge. [1]
  • On Mar 28, 2025, US District Judge John Bates blocked the part of the EO targeting contracts and access to government buildings for Jenner and Block. Bates cited that the EO threatened the existence of the law firm, due to them not being able to access federal courthouses and 40% of their contracts coming from the federal government. [1]
    • 3/27/2025 EO 14250 Addressing Risks from WilmerHale
  • Suspends all security clearances for the WilmerHale lawfirm. Blacklists WilmerHale from contracting with the government. Blacklists WilmerHale employees from entring government buildings or working in the government. [1]
  • WilmerHale was the 5th lawfirm Trump targeted in connection with his political adversaries. Trump targeted WilmerHale due to their ties to Robert Muller, who retired from the firm in 2021. WilmerHale requires security clearance for clients such as Apple, Harvard, Meta, and Tesla. [1]
  • On Mar 28, 2025, US District Judge Richard Leon blocked Trump from resitricting access to government buildings fo WilmerHale, but refused to block the contract part of the EO. The same day, lawfirm Skadden Arps agreed to dedicate $100 million in free legal services to the Trump admin for veterans and other grops and also committed to "merit-based hiring". [1]
  • On April 1, 2025, Willkie Farr & Gallagher, Kamala's husband's lawfirm, also agreed to $100 mln in free work from the Trump admin and an end to its DEI practices. [1]
    • 3/27/2025 EO 14251 Restoring Truth and Sanity to American History
  • Directs Vance to work with the Smithsonian to scrub any "improper, divisive or anti-American ideology" from their properties, including American racial history and no trans people. Directs funding to improve the infrastructure of Independence National Historical Park before July 4, 2026 (250th anniversary of American independence). Directs that any statues/monuments that were taken down after Jan 2020 be reinstated. [1]
  • The Smithsonian spans 21 museums, most of them in DC lining the mall from the U.S. Capitol to the Washington Monument. In 2017, Trump previosuly defended protestors in Charlottesville, Virginia, who protested the removal of Robert E. Lee, saying there were "very fine people of both sides" of the fight, which sparked widespread outrage. [1]
    • 3/27/2025 EO 14252 Exclusions from Federal Labor-Management Relations Programs
  • Executive Order: Adds additional national secrurity and foreign service exclusions to Reagan EO 12171. Directs agencies to end collective bargaining with federal unions. [1]
  • Collective Bargaining in the US: Affected agencies include the Departments of State, Defense, Veterans Affairs, Energy, Health and Human Services, Treasury, Justice and Commerce and the part of Homeland Security Police and firefighters will continue to collectively bargain. Trump said the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 gives him the authority to end collective bargaining with federal unions to safeguard national security. Earlier in March, DHS ended a collective bargaining agreement with the tens of thousands of TSA employees. [1]
  • Lawsuit against the EO: On April 25, 2025, US District Judge Paul Friedman in DC issued an injunction blocking the EO pending the outcome of a lawsuit by the National Treasury Employees Union, which represents about 160,000 federal employees. On May 6, 2025, despite Friedman's order, Trump cancelled a collective bargaining session with the FDA. [1] [2]
    • 3/28/2025 EO 14253 Making the District of Columbia Safe and Beautiful
  • Establishes a D.C. Safe and Beautiful Task Force to work with local law enforcement to keep DC safe. The task force should focus on illegal immigration and crime. The task force should also expidite conceal carry applications. Orders the planning of the beautification of facilities, monuments, land, parks, and roadways in DC. [1]
  • Trump has long complained about homeless encampments and crime in the capital. However, Trump's order came as Washington DC was gutting their workforce, leaving its buildings vacant. In 2024, DC violent crime was down 35% from 2023. As of Mar 2025, DC violent crime was down 9% compared to 2024, despite there already being 30 homicides, an 11% YOY increase. [1]
    • 3/31/2025 EO 14254 Combating Unfair Practices in the Live Entertainment Market
  • Directs the FTC to enforce all laws for ticket scalpers including the Better Online Tickets Sales Act (2016) and all tax laws. Orders the FTC to submit a report for regulation recommendations to stop ticket scalpers. [1]
  • Trump signed thr EO with singer Kid Rock standing next to him. The order aimed at enforcing competition regulations to combat the growing use of bots on sites like Ticketmaster, who has 70% market share. [1]
    • 3/31/2025 EO 14255 Establishing the United States Investment Accelerator
  • Orders the Secretary of Commerce to establish the United States Investment Accelerator facilitate and accelerate investments in the US that are above $1 billion. [1]
  • The Investment Accelerator also took over the CHIPS Act program. [1]
    • 4/2/2025 EO 14256 Regulating Imports with a Reciprocal Tariff to Rectify Trade Practices that Contribute to Large and Persistent Annual United States Goods Trade Deficits
  • Executive Order: Declared a national emergency under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) and the National Emergencies Act (NEA) due to "large and persistent annual U.S. goods trade deficits". Under the emergency, imposes "reciprocal" 10% tariffs on all imports with further tariffs on 50+ countries (full list) at a base rate of at least 10%. The tariffs go into effect on April 9, 2025. Duty free de minimis items are exempt until Lutnick puts in place a way to collect the tariffs. Canada and Mexico were exempt from the new tariffs. [1]
  • International Fallout response: In response automaker Stellantis said it would temporarily lay off U.S. workers and close plants in Canada and Mexico, while General Motors said it would increase U.S. production. Howard Lutnick and senior trade adviser Peter Navarro both Trump would not back off, and that the tariff increases were not a negotiation. However, Trump later said, "The tariffs give us great power to negotiate." The Dow dropped 4% (worst since June 2020), the S&P500 dropped 5%, and the Nasdaq fell 6% (worst since March 2020) due to resurging inflation and recession worries. For the week, the S&P 500 fell 9.08%, the Nasdaq declined 10.02%, and the Dow fell 7.86%. The Russell 2000 Small Cap Index dropped 9.70%, confirming a bear market. Imports to the United States now face an average duty of 22.5%, up from 2.5% in 2024. The tariffs also alienated allies in Asia and undercut US strategic efforts to contain China. On April 28, 2025, UPS said they were laying off 20,000 people due to tariffs making them need to cut costs. [1] [2]
  • The problem with tariffs: [1]
    1. Retaliation: the tariffs cause other countries to retaliate, not buy from the US anymore, dump their US bonds to raise rate on US debt (China has $769 bln and Japan has $1.01 tln)
    2. Supply chains: products today take a lot of parts, these parts come from all over the world meaning tariffs will drive up the price of manufacuring massively and cause stagflation.
    3. Reduced military spending: if the tariffs cause a recession that will decrease tax revenue, which will decrease defense spending, which will be worse for manufacturing, which is what the tariffs were meant to be for.
    4. Recession from uncertainty: uncertainty means no investments, which means no sales and no economic growth, with means recession.
    5. Recession from lower consumer activity: if consumers think the tariffs with go away in 2029 with a new administration they will wait to spend money, which will cause a recession.
    6. Lower trade deficits: if the US is not importing as much then other countries will have less US dollars, which means they will buy less treasury bonds, which means the US debt rate will increase (1% increase in intrest rates means +80B in annual US debt payments).
    7. Mistrust of the US: the tariffs included Taiwan and the EU, which are not countries and shows the lack of a plan of caring that went into crafting tariff policy, if people stop trusting the US then the reserve currency status of the US is at stake.
  • Senate intervenes: The same day of the EO, the Senate passed a bill that would terminate new tariffs on Canada. 4 Republicans, Susan Collins, Lisa Murkowski, Mitch McConnell and Rand Paul, joined all Dems in a 51-48 vote, the House is unlikely to pass the bill. The bill aimed to terminate the national emergency Trump had delcared to impose the tariffs. On April 3, Republican Senator Chuck Grassley and Democrat Maria Cantwell also introduced legislation that would require Trump to notify Congress on new tariffs with an explanation of the rationale and impact of them. On April 30, 2025, following the first negative GDP print in 3 years, the Senate failed to pass, 49-49, a bill to overturn Trump's reciprocal tariffs by nullifying Trump's "national emergency". Then Senate Majority Leader John Thune moved to permanently kill the bill having Vance cast a 50-49 tiebreaking vote, since 2 votes in favor of the bill were not there and would be the next day. [1] [2] [3]
  • Tariff "calculation": Trump's formula for calculating the tariffs was to take the U.S. goods trade deficit with a country, divide it by that country's exports to the U.S. and turn it into a percentage figure; then cut that figure in half to produce the U.S. "reciprocal" tariff, with a floor of 10%. This ended up making the uninhabited volcanic Australian territory of Heard Island and McDonald Islands in the Antarctic, largely inhabited by penguins, have a 10% tariff. This also disproportionately hurt the poorest countries in the world such as Madagascar (47% reciprocal tariff, $500 GDP per capita, $733 million of US exports), Lesotho (50% reciprocal tariff), Cambodia (49% reciprocal tariff). These countries are so poor they cannot import any US goods due to them being so expensive (they aren't buying Teslas), so they got punished with the sharpest tariff rates as a result. [1] [2]
  • Tariff reversal: On April 9, 2025, less than 24 hours after the tariffs went into effect and in a complete reversal due to the markets getting hammered, Trump issued a 90 day pause on all reciprocal tariffs except for on China. In response to the news, indexes erased their lossed, shooting up 10%. [1]
  • Trump sued for tariffs: On April 14, 2025, the nonpartisan Liberty Justice Center on behalf of five small U.S. businesses sued Trump in the U.S. Court of International Trade, seeking to block his tariffs. [1]
  • Trump and Jerome Powell: After the tariff announcement, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said the Fed is keeping rates on hold, concerned tariffs will drive up inflation. Trump responded to this by saying Powell's termination "cannot come fast enough," while calling for the U.S. central bank to cut interest rates, pressure Powell said he would resist. Powell's term ends in May 2026, when Trump will get to appoint a new chair. In the coming weeks, Trump threatened that he could fire Powell if he wanted to and replace him with Kevn Warsh (former Fed governor) or Kevin Hassett (Trump econ adviser). However, on April 22, 2025, Trump said "I have no intention of firing him," and "I would like to see him be a little more active in terms of his idea to lower interest rates," causing markets to jump. On May 4, 2025, Trump fully backed off, saying it would be ridiculous to fire Powell but still called on him to lower rates. [1] [2] [3] [4]
  • Tariff deals: On May 8, 2025, the US and UK made the first tariff trade deal, with the base 10% US tariff rate staying in place but some specific industry tariffs dropped. [1]
  • China Trade war ceasefire: On May 12, 2025, the US and China agreed to a temporary truce in their tariff trade war, after days of talks mediated in Switzerland. The deal leaves US tariffs on China at 30% and China tariffs on the US at 10% from May 14 to August 12. [1]
    • 4/2/2025 EO 14257 Further Amendment to Duties Addressing the Synthetic Opioid Supply Chain in the People's Republic of China as Applied to Low-Value Imports
  • Reimposed tariffs on duty-free de minimis items (under $800) from China and Hong Kong that had been given an exception under EO 14200. Tariffs go into affect on May 2, 2025. Tariff rates include 30% ad valorem duty, $25-50 specific duty, Orders Secretary of Commerce to submit a report within 90 days on if to extend the tariffs to Macau (Chinese administrative district). [1]
  • Trump made the EO after Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick certified "adequate systems are in place to collect tariff revenue." 90% of all packages coming into the U.S. enter via de minimis, about 60% from China, led by direct-to-consumer retailers such as Temu and Shein. [1]
    • 4/4/2025 EO 14258 Extending the TikTok Enforcement Delay
  • Executive Order: Extended the TikTok enforcement delay until until June 19, 2025. [1]
    • 4/8/2025 EO 142 Strengthening The Reliability And Security Of The United States Electric Grid
  • Directs the Secretary of Energy to analyze energy regulations to make sure they don't effect power grid reserves. [1]
    • 4/8/2025 EO 142 Protecting American Energy From State Overreach
  • Directs the AG to go after states who have any climate change regulations that interfere with Trump's energy agenda. [1]
  • The EO seeks to block any state laws that address climate change, ESG initiatives, environmental justice and carbon emissions. The U.S. Climate Alliance, group of 24 governors dedicated to climate action, in a statement to the EO saying they would nt back down from continuing climate change policies. [1]
    • 4/8/2025 EO 142 Reinvigorating America's Beautiful Clean Coal Industry and Amending Executive Order 14241
  • Executive Order: Designates coal as a mineral so it gets the benefits from EO 14241. Directs the Interior, Agriculture, and Energy departments to submit a report on increasing domestic coal production within 60 days. Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to prioritize coal leasing on public lands. Directs agancies to reduce coal mining regulations. Ends the moratorium that paused new coal leasing. Directs agencies to start coal mines in places were there will be AI datacenters. [1]
  • Coal in the US: In 2025, coal-burning plants generated less than 20% of U.S. electricity, a drop from 50% in 2000, due to more fracking, more use of solar/wind power, and regulations from Dems, including Biden. This EO uses the 1950 Defense Production Act to boost coal production. Coal releases more of the main greenhouse gas carbon dioxide than any other fossil fuel when burned and emits pollutants linked to lung and heart diseases. [1]
  • Coal exemptions: On April 15, 2025, Trump exempted 47 companies from regulations to curb mercury and air toxics for their coal-fired power plants. The SC previously declined to block the Biden-era Mercury and Air Toxics Standard that required constant monitoring of emissions. Mercury and other air toxics associated with coal burning raise the risk of asthma attacks, strokes, heart attacks and lung cancer. [1]
  • Part 90 Program Cut: Part 90 is a federal program ran by the Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA) and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) which relocates coal miners diagnosed with black lung to safer jobs at the same pay. However, as part of the DOGE cuts, the Part 90 program was halted due to staff cuts (875 of 1000 NIOSH workers were fired by DOGE). The cuts also shut down a seperate decades-old program to help detect black lung in coal miners NIOSH estimates that 20% of coal miners in Central Appalachia suffer from black lung, the highest rate in 25 years. The cuts also affected MHSA, including coal mine inspectors who enforce coal safety regulations, the cuts will make it almost impossible to enforce the regulations now. On April 29, 2025, NIOSH rehired 40 employees who worked on coal miner health and firefighter fatality prevention programs. On May 3, 2025, Trump again fired 2 of the 40 NIOSH workers that had been asked back and said they were cutting the coal miner health and firefighter programs. On May 13, 2025, over 100 federal employees who screen coal miners for black lung disease were permanently reinstated. [1] [2] [3] [4]
    • 4/8/2025 EO 142 Amendment to Reciprocal Tariffs and Updated Duties as Applied to Low-Value Imports from the People's Republic of China
  • Increases the China tariffs from 34% to 84%. Increases de minimis tariff from 30% to 90%. [1]
  • China responded by raising their tariffs on the US to 8%4 also. [1]
    • 4/9/2025 EO 142 Maintaining Acceptable Water Pressure In Showerheads
  • Repeals Obama-era regulation defining what a showerhead is and limiting showerhead pressure. [1]
  • Trump had complained about the shower pressure regulation for years. It was an Obama regulation that was brought back by Biden. The regulation limited the flow for each showerhead on the market to 2.5 gallons (9.5 liters) of water per minute. [1]
    • 4/9/2025 EO 142 Reforming Foreign Defense Sales to Improve Speed and Accountability
  • Sets policy increase accountability and transparency for US foreign weapons transfers. Directs agencies to work with Congress to achieve this policy and to work to make US arms buyers independent from the US. [1]
  • Under the U.S. Arms Export Control Act, Congress has the right to review arms exports to other countries, depending if country is an ally and the size of the sale. In Trump's first term, he criticized Congress for delaying foreign arms sales over human rights or other concerns. In 2019, Trump infuriated lawmakers (including Rebuplicans) when he declared a national emergency because of Iran, allowing him to sidestep Congress and sent $8 bln in weapons to Saudi Arabia, UAE, and Jordan. Congress was blocking the sale due to the civilian death toll in teh Saudi campaign on Yemen and human rights abuses such as the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi at a Saudi consulate in Turkey. [1]
    • 4/9/2025 EO 142 Zero-Based Regulatory Budgeting to Unleash American Energy
  • Directs agencies to issue a sunset rule (regulation termination) no later than Sept 30, 2025 to end regulations under specific laws Trump calls out in the EO. Directs agencies to make no new regulations unless they last less than 5 years. Orders all new agencies to first be brought to the public for a cost benefit analysis. Agencies shall implement the order by working with their DOGE team lead. Agencies include Environmental Protection Agency (EPA); the Department of Energy (DoE); the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC); and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). It further applies to the following agency subcomponents: the Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement (OSMRE), the Bureau of Land Management (BLM), the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management (BOEM), the Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement (BSEE), and the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS), all within the Department of the Interior; and the United States Army Corps of Engineers (ACE), within the United States Army. [1]
  • The EO aimed at targeting and reducing energy regulations. The directive covers all regulations under the Federal Power Act, the Natural Gas Act and the Power Plant and Industrial Fuel Use Act. Ari Peskoe, director of Harvard Law School's Electricity Law Initiative, said the EO is "impossible to implement, blatantly illegal, creates massive amounts of unnecessary work, and just makes no sense" and "is deeply misguided and reveals a fundamental misunderstanding of how agencies work." [1]
    • 4/9/2025 EO 142 Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers
  • Directs agencies to work with the FTC to terminate any regulations that create defacto monopolies, create unnecessary barriers to entry for new market participants, limit competition, or result in any other anti-comptitiveness. Within 70 days, any anti-competitive resulations should be sent to the FTC chairman and the AG. Directs the FTC to issued a request for information (RFI) from the public for 40 days on any anti-competitive regulations. [1]
    • 4/9/2025 EO 142 Restoring America's Maritime Dominance
  • Directs agencies to submit a Maritime Action Plan (MAP) to Trump within 210 days to increase the US commercial shipbuilding capacity and maritime workforce. Part of the MAP should include funding to improve the shipbuilding industrial base and make domestic ship building not reliant on foreign countries. Orders the investigation of China for their dominance targeting of maritime, logistics, and shipbuilding sectors (possible future tariffs). Orders the CBP to strictly enforce harbor maintenance fees for foreign cargo vessels. Establishes a Maritime Security Trust Fund to fund MAP programs. Directs the Secretary of Commerce to make maritime prosperity zones that are deregulatory havens for shipbuilders. Orders agencies to expand maritime sector training and education. Directs increased funding to the United States Merchant Marine Academy. Directs DOGE to look at the DOD amd DHS for vessel procurement inefficiencies. Orders a legislative proposal on ship building to Congress within 180 days. Orders the overall deregulation of the shipbuilding industry. [1]
  • Republican and Democratic U.S. lawmakers for years have warned about China's growing dominance on the seas and diminishing U.S. naval readiness. The EO included million-dollar U.S. port docking fees for Chinese vessels. The US built less than 1% of commercial ships globally at the time of the EO, compared with China at 50%. US shipbuilding peaked in the 1970s but declined due to high costs and a complex regulatory structure. [1]
    • 4/9/2025 EO 142 Modernizing Defense Acquisitions And Spurring Innovation In The Defense Industrial Base
  • Directs the Secretary of Defense to make a report within 60 days on reforming US defense aquisitions Directs the Secretary of Defense to review all regulations related to defense aquisitions. Directs the Secretary of Defense to make a report within 120 days to expand the US defense aquisition workforce. Directs the Secretary of Defense to review within 90 days all major defense acquisition programs (MDAPs) to confirm with this EO. This review includes cancelling any program more than 15% behind schedule or over 15% program baseline cost. [1]
    • 4/9/2025 EO 142 Addressing Risks From Susman Godfrey
  • Executive Order: Revokes all security clearances for the Susman Godfrey lawfirm. Terminates all government contracts with Susman Godfrey. Bans all Susman Godfrey employees from government buildings or working in the government. [1]
  • Susan Godfrey: Represented Dominion Voting Systems in defamation cases related to the 2020 U.S. election, including the $787.5 million settlement Fox News case. [1]
  • Other lawfirms caputilating: On April 11 2025, Kirkland & Ellis, A&O Shearman, Simpson Thacher and Latham & Watkins each agreed to do $125 mln in free work for the government, while Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft agreed to $100 mln. The 5 lawfirms agreed to also end their DEI programs in exchange for Trump not giving them similar EOs. The deals brought the total free legal work to $940 mln. [1]
  • Judge blocks Susan Godfrey EO: On April 15, 2025, US District Judge Loren AliKhan issued a TRO blocking part of Trump's EO after Susan Godfrey sued Trump for his move.
