The TRO included a block on the cancelling of contracts and restricting access to government buildings. AliKhan's order is the third TRO issued in relation to Trump's EOs on lawfirms. [1]
    • 4/9/2025 EO 142 Modifying Reciprocal Tariff Rates To Reflect Trading Partner Retaliation And Alignment
  • Modifies all reciprocal tariffs from EO 14256 to only be 10% for the next 90 days. Changes the reciprocal tariffs on China from 84% to 125% starting April 10 (effectively 145% tariff due to the fentanyl tariffs too). Changes the China de minimis tariffs from 90% to 120%. [1]
  • China responded with their own 125% tariffs on the US and began working with Europe and Southeast Asia to counter the US. [1]
  • On April 13, 2025, Trump excluded smartphones, computers, and other semiconductors/electronics, largely imported from China, from his reciprocal tariffs. The exclusion brought the tariffs to 0% for these items, rather than the 10% baseline he had for the original pause. [1]
    • 4/15/2025 EO 142 Restoring Common Sense To Federal Procurement
  • Executive Order: Orders the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) can contain nly provisions required by statute or essential to sound procurement, anything else should be removed. Directs each agency to appoint a senior acquisition or procurement official to ensure further agency alignment with FAR reform. Any regulations not terminated from the FAR and not required by law should be considered for a 4 year sunset. [1]
  • Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR): FAR is the primary regulation for use by all executive agencies in their acquisition of supplies and services with appropriated funds. [1]
    • 4/15/2025 EO 142 Lowering Drug Prices By Once Again Putting Americans First
  • Executive Order: Directs the HHS to issue guidance for and work with Congress to modify the Medicare Drug Price Negotiation Program. Directs the HHS to develop a new payment program model for Medicare high-cost drugs within 1 year. Directs the HHS to adjust Medicare so Medicare payments align with the cost of drg aquisition. Directs agencies to provide recommendations to Trump on how to ensure that manufacturers pay accurate Medicaid drug rebates. Directs the HHS to ensure future grants under the Public Health Service Act require health centers to make insulin and injectable epinephrine available at or below the discounted price paid by the health center. Directs the FDA to improve the Importation Program to make it easier for States to obtain approval. Directs agencies to take steps to reduce anti-competitive behavior from pharmeceutical manufacturers. [1]
  • Pharaceutical Lobby Win: The Medicare Drug Price Negotiation Program was from Biden's Inflation Reduction Act. When drugs have no competition, the INA now allows the government to negotiate prices for complex biologic/biotech, drugs after 13 years on the market, but after 9 years for drugs taken as pills and capsules. Since its signing, drugmakers have been lobbying to delay the timeline for price negotiations for small molecule drugs (primarily pills and account for most medicines) to 13 years as well. The EO gives the drugmakers a win by pushing for Congress to revamp the program with this change. [1]
    • 4/15/2025 EO 142 Ensuring National Security And Economic Resilience Through Section 232 Actions On Processed Critical Minerals And Derivative Products
  • Executive Order: Orders the Secretary of Commerce to conduct an investigation under section 232 Trade Expansion Act of 1962 into critical mineral imports The investigation should assess if the current US critical mineral importing is a national security risk. [1]
  • Critical Minerals in the US: The ordering of the investigation was seen as a an escalation and precursor to Trump issuing new critical mineral tariffs. Manufacturers, industry consultants, and academics have long warned that the US is too reliant on foreign imports of critical minerals that power the entire US economy. China is the top producer of 30 of the 50 critical minerals. After Trump's reciprocal tariffs, China imposed restrictions on rare earths (group of 17 elements used across the defense, electric vehicle, energy and electronics) to the US, showing their ability to weaponize their critical mineral dominance. [1]
    • 4/15/2025 EO 142 Restoring Common Sense to Federal Office Space Management
  • Executive Order: Revokes Carter EO 12072 of (Federal Space Management) and Clinton EO 13006 of (Locating Federal Facilities on Historic Properties in Our Nation's Central Cities). The previous EOs directed agencies "to prioritize central business districts and historic properties and districts when selecting locations for federal facilities." Orders the GSA to only select cost-effective facilities going forward. [1] [2]
    • 4/16/2025 EO 142 Ensuring Commercial, Cost-Effective Solutions In Federal Contracts
  • Executive Order: Directs agency contracting officers to review all pending contracts for non-commercial products or services within 60 days and submit waivers justifying their necessity. Directs more oversight from agency's approval authorities whenever an agency proposes a non-commerical product/service. [1] [2]
    • 4/17/2025 EO 14276 Restoring American Seafood Competitiveness
  • Executive Order: Orders the Sec of Commerce to suspend, revise, or rescind all regulations that are burdensome to commercial domestic fishing. Directs the National Marine Fisheries Service to incorporate less expensive and more reliable technologies. Orders the creation of an America First Seafood Strategy to promote production, marketing, sale, and export of United States fishery and aquaculture products. Orders the creations of a US seafood trading strategy. Directs the Sec of Commerce to review all marine national monuments to see which ones can be opened for fishing. Trump went on to sign a proclomation allowing commercial fishing in Pacific Islands Heritage Marine National Monument on the same day of the EO. [1]
  • US Fishing Industry: The EO marked a shift in US policy away from efforts to increase fish supply to prioritizing commerical fishing intrests. Trump cited the $20 bln US trade deficit in fishing as a reason for his order, the US iports 90% of its seafood despite controlling over 4 mln sq miles of prime fishing grounds. Since 1976, US fishing has been governed by the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act, which intended to combat overfishing. Under the act, NOAA's National Marine Fisheries Service develops management plans for 45 fisheries, setting quotas and determining the start and close of fishing seasons, after talking to researchers and local fisherman. The list of overfished list grew from 40 in 2013 to 47 in 2023, overfishing had led to the destruction of the Maine shrip, Alantic cod, and partially the West Coast salmon industry. The US has a $320 million fishing industry, the Trump admin's regulatory freeze injected chaos that delayed the opening of some East Coast fisheries and led to overfishing of Atlantic bluefin tuna. [1] [2] [3]
  • New England fishing monument: On May 9, 2025, Trump signed a proclamation restoring commercial fishing access to the Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument off New England. The monument was designated by Obama in 2016 to protect species including deep-sea corals, sea turtles and whales, Trump reopened it in 2020 but Biden again reversed it in 2021. [1]
    • 4/23/2025 EO 1427X Advancing Artificial Intelligence Education for American Youth
  • Executive Order: Establishes an Artificial Intelligence Education Task Force responsible for promoting AI literacy and proficiency among Americans. Orders the creation of an AI "challenge" competition within 90 days, where students can compete for AI achievements. Orders the task force to work with private industry to provide AI resources to K-12 education. Orders the Secretary of Education to prioritize grants to teacher training programs for AI. Orders the Secretary of Labor to increase participation in AI-related Registered Apprenticeships [1]
  • A1: The order came after Education Secretary Linda McMahon confuses AI calling it "A1" while at an education summit. [1]
    • 4/23/2025 EO 1427X Restoring Equality Of Opportunity And Meritocracy
  • Executive Order: Sets policy to eliminate the use of disparate-impact liability. Revokes two presidential regulations, from 1966 and from 1973. Orders agencies to stop enforcing acts that contain disparate-impact liability. Orders the repeal or amending of all Title VI regulations that have disparate-impact liability. Orders the AG to drop all cases that rely on disparate-impact liability. Orders agencies to prevent any future disparate-impact liability regulations from being implemented in the future. [1]
  • Disparate-impact liability: Disparate-impact liability is the idea that racism, sexism, or some other form of discrimination can occur without explicit intent. It was created as a liability path in the 1971 SC case Griggs v. Duke Power, where the court said that otherwise neutral employment practices can violate the Civil Rights Act when they disproportionately affect a protected group and are not demonstrably related to job performance. In 1991, Congress amended the Civil Rights Act to explicitly protects against practices seen in Griggs. Prior to the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA), women could be asked to have a male relative or spouse co-sign for their credit cards or loans. In the EO, Trump tries to argue that it is somehow violating civil rights law and the Constitution to require employers or housing providers to consider the disparate impact on race or gender or age, right or disability. The EO is likely to make sure that women have equal access to credit, that Black people have equal access to credit. [1] [2]
    • 4/23/2025 EO 1427X Reinstating Common Sense School Discipline Policies
  • Executive Order: Orders the Secretary of Education to issue guidance to states on school discipline and their obligations not to engage in racial discrimination under Title VI in all contexts, including school discipline. Orders an investigation into Title VI discipline-related policies, how NGOs use federal grants to promote "discriminatory-equity-ideology-based" discipline techniques, and how to model school discipline policies that "promote common sense." [1]
  • Obama/Biden school discipline: The EO reverses Obama policies that urged schools to equalize discipline rates across racial groups, often under threat of losing federal funding. Trump rolled these back in 2018, but Biden reinstated them in 2023. [1]
    • 4/23/2025 EO 1427X Preparing Americans for High-Paying Skilled Trade Jobs of the Future
  • Executive Order: Orders the Secretary of Labor, Commerce, and Education to work on a report in 90 days on how to reindustrialize the US workforce. The report should include workforce development programs, promotion of innovation, upskilling workers, finding alternative credentials to 4-year college degree. The same secretaries should also submit another report within 120 days on how to reach and surpass 1 million new active apprentices in the Registered Apprenticeship program. [1]
  • Tariffs: The aim of the tariffs is to onshore American manufacturing, this can only be done if the skilled manufacturing laborforce is there. This EO aims to shift agencies away from overwhelming support for the professional jobs that colleges and universities prepare workers for, and toward backing skilled trades, like electricians, machinists and nursing assistants. Such jobs that require significant training, credentials and apprenticeships, but not a four-year college degree. [1]
    • 4/23/2025 EO 1427X White House Initiative To Promote Excellence And Innovation At Historically Black Colleges And Universities
  • Executive Order: Establishes the White House Initiative on Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) Initiative, to be housed in the WH. The initiative should work with agencies and HBCUs to provide support higher education opportunities for HBCUs, with an annual progress report to the president on their achievements. Establishes in the Department of Education the President's Board of Advisors on Historically Black Colleges and Universities. The HBCU board will implement the HBCU PARTNERS Act from Trump's first term (2019-2020). [1]
  • Historically Black Colleges and Universities: Presidents have issued EOs related to HBCUs, with variations in title and scope, since President Jimmy Carter began formally centering HBCUs in federal policy in 1980. However, Trump's EO lacks a commitment to new federal funding, compared to Biden's pairing his 2021 executive order with nearly $1.6 billion in funding announced within a week of the executive order. Trump later released a fact sheet refrerring to HBCU-related funding from his first term. Between 2021 and 2024, Biden directed $17 billion, including $1.3 billion in 2024 alone. As of 2025, many HBCUs still struggle with inadequate infrastructure, lower faculty pay, and limited state investment, especially compared to nearby HWIs. [1] [2]
    • 4/23/2025 EO 1427X Reforming Accreditation To Strengthen Higher Education
  • Executive Order: Orders the Sec of Education to "hold accountable" accreditators who require institutions to engage in "unlawful discrimination." Orders the AG to go after law schools who have DEI requirements. Orders the termination of "unlawful discrimination" or DEI by American medical schools or graduate medical education entities Orders the Sec of Education to ensure accreditation requires higher education institutions to provide high-quality education, do not implement DEI policies, have intellecual diversity (means more conservatives). [1]
  • Accreditation: College accreditation is a requirement for accessing federal student financial aid. The federal government does not directly accredit U.S. universities but has a role in overseeing the mostly private organizations that do so. Under the Higher Education Act of 1965, the education secretary "recognizes" over 30 private educational associations, as well as some agencies run by state governments, that can accredit colleges through a peer review process if they meet criteria laid out by Congress. The Higher Education Act says the main role of accreditors is to ensure the quality of education and to serve as a guarantor of the diplomas issued by accredited schools. The Higher Education Act requires institutions provide info for current and prospective students on "student body diversity," including a breakdown of the gender and racial makeup of full-time students. Trump has often complained that accreditors approve institutions that fail to provide quality education and promote "leftist" ideology. [1] [2]
    • 4/23/2025 EO 1427X Transparency Regarding Foreign Influence at American Universities
  • Executive Order: Orders strict enforcement of the requirement of higher education institutions to report their foreign funding sources. Directs the AG to "hold accountable" any university that doesn't comply. Directs the Secretary of Education to stop federal funding to universities that do no comply. [1]
  • Berkely investigation: On April 25, 2025, the Dept of Education launched an investigation into the University of California, Berkeley's foreign funding disclosures. The investigation came after a review found Berkeley's disclosures to the government may be "incomplete or inaccurate." [1]
    • 4/24/2025 EO 1427X Unleashing America's Offshore Critical Minerals And Resources
  • Executive Order: Directs the Secretary of Commerce within 60 days to expedite the process for reviewing and issuing seabed mineral exploration licenses and commercial recovery permits. Directs the Secretary of Commerce to take further steps to ensure the US is a leader in seabed mineral exploration and recovery. Directs the DOD and DOE to submit a report on using the National Defense Stockpile for physical or virtual storage of materials derived from seabed. [1]
  • Deep sea mining in the US: The EO orders the expidition of seabed mining permits "in areas beyond the national jurisdiction," a move likely to spark friction with the international community. Any country can allow deep-sea mining in its own territorial waters, roughly up to 200 nautical miles from shore. The order is another push by Trump to onshore critical mineral production from China, who restricted exports to the US in recent months due to tariffs. [1]
    • 4/24/2025 EO 1427X Strengthening Probationary Periods In The Federal Service
  • Executive Order: Issues a new Civil Service Rule XI so that agencies will have to affirmatively determine that the continued employment of individuals serving probationary or trial periods (1-2 years) would benefit the Federal service before such appointments are finalized. [1]
  • Probationary workers: Before the order, probationary workers had automatically attained full status after the trial period unless they were fired. Most probationary workers are longtime government employees in new roles. On Feb 2025, Trump fired 25000 probationary workers, saying it was for poor performance; most were ordered reinstated by a federal judge. [1]
    • 4/28/2025 EO 1427X Enforcing Commonsense Rules of the Road for America's Truck Drivers
  • Executive Order: Orders increased enforcement of the requirement of English proficiency for American truck drivers. Orders the Secretary of Transportation to make any new regulations that will help the working conditions of American truck drivers. [1]
  • [1]
    • 4/28/2025 EO 1427X Protecting American Communities From Criminal Aliens
  • Executive Order: Orders the AG to make a list of sanctuary cities. Orders all cities on the list to have their federal funding terminated and have the DOJ go after them if they don't comply with Trump. [1]
  • Lawsuit against the EO: On May 8, 2025, US District Judge William Orrick in San Francisco ordered Trump not to use this new EO to bypass an earlier PI that Orrick previously issued in relation to sanctuary cities. Orrick said that if this order was used to target funds unrelated to sanctuary policies, their suspension would violate the U.S. Constitution. [1]
    • 4/28/2025 EO 1427X Strengthening And Unleashing America's Law Enforcement To Pursue Criminals And Protect Innocent Citizens
  • Executive Order: Orders the AG to provide legal resources (including pro bono work) to law enforcement officers who "unjustly incur expenses" for actions taken on the job. Orders agencies to provide guidance to states on more agressive law enforcement, more police training, increased police pay, increased legal protections for police officers, seek stronger sentences for crimes against law enforcement, more funding for prisons. Orders the DOJ and DOD to increase the military coordination with police officers. Orders the AG to go after states that are not 100% law enforement simps or who use DEI to go against law enforcement. Orders the Homeland Security Task Forces from EO 14159 (Protecting the American People Against Invasion) to enforce this order too. [1]
  • [1]
    • 4/29/2025 EO 1427X Addressing Certain Tariffs on Imported Articles
  • Executive Order: Orders that all Trump's tariffs are not stackable. [1]
  • Auto tariff adjustment: In a seperate proclomation, Trump agreed to give carmakers 2 years to boost domestic manufacturing. He did this by allowing them to offset tariffs for imported auto parts used in U.S.-assembled vehicles equal to 3.75% of the total value of the suggested retail price of vehicles they build in the U.S. through April 2026, and 2.5% of U.S. production through April 30, 2027. The order came as the 25% auto tariffs already hurt the auto industry and US auto leaders lobbied Trump heavily to provide them relief. The proclomation does not change the 25% auto tariffs however. [1] [2]
    • 5/1/2025 EO 1427X Establishment of the Religious Liberty Commission
  • Executive Order: Establishes the Religious Liberty Commission with 14 members and 2 year terms. Commission is to write a report on religious freedom in the US, advise the WH on executive action for religious liberty, Trump named Texas Lieutenant Gov. Dan Patrick to head the commission At the signing event, Trump said "They say, 'separation between church and state' … I said, 'All right, let's forget about that for one time.'" [1] [2]
    • 5/1/2025 EO 1427X Ending Taxpayer Subsidization of Biased Media
  • Executive Order: Orders the US Corporation for Public Broadcasting and all other agencies to terminate any funding to PBS and NPR because Trump thinks they are biased and spread 'radical woke propaganda'. [1]
  • PBS and NPR: PBS gets 15% of their funding and NPR gets 2% of their funding from CPB. [1]
    • 5/5/2025 EO 1427X Improving The Safety And Security Of Biological Research
  • Executive Order: Orders the termination of federal funding of "dangerous" gain-of-function research conducted by foreign entities in countries of concern (Iran and China). Orders the rewriting of the 2024 "United States Government Policy for Oversight of Dual Use Research of Concern and Pathogens with Enhanced Pandemic Potential" to have more top-down oversight and the enforcement of the GOF directive from above. Orders increased tracking of GOF research. Orders institutions that get federal funding must report any GOF research and prohibits any further federal funding to institutions that fund foreign GOF research. [1]
  • Gain of function research: The EO pauses all federal funding to gain of function research until "until a safer, more enforceable, and transparent policy governing such research can be developed." Gain-of-function research studies enhancements to pathogens such as Avian influenza, SARS and the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome or MERS viruses. The order comes after conservatives lost their minds over Fauci funding for EcoHealth Alliance and Wuhan Institute of Virology, claiming they manufactured the SARS-CoV2 virus. [1]
    • 5/5/2025 EO 1427X Regulatory Relief to Promote Domestic Production of Critical Medicines
  • Executive Order: Orders the HHS to review existing regulations that pertain to the development of domestic pharmaceutical manufacturing for termination. Orders the FDA to improve their risk-based inspection regime. Orders the EPA to update regulations that apply to the inspection and approval of new and expanded manufacturing capacity of pharmaceutical products. Makes the EPA the lead agency for the permitting of pharmaceutical manufacturing facilities. [1]
  • US Drug Manufacturing: The EO aims to reduce the time it takes to approve pharmaceutical plants. Analysts and companies have estimated that a new manufacturing plant could take at least five years to build. The EO comes as Trump prepares to tariff pharmaceuticals, which the U.S. imports more than $200 billion of. [1]
    • 5/9/2025 EO 1427X Fighting Overcriminalization In Federal Regulations
  • Executive Order: Orders that criminal enforcement of criminal regulatory offenses is discouraged. Orders prosecution of criminal regulatory offenses only when the person knowingly breaks the regulations. Orders all future criminal regulations/rules to have a mens rea requirement. Orders agencies publicly post a list of regulatory violations that can trigger criminal charges, and guidance on the circumstances under which they would refer violators for prosecution. Says that all immigration regulations are excempted from this EO. [1]
  • Context: The EO was intended to ease the burden on small businesses that do not have the same compliance resources as large corporations. Federal crinimal regulations have long been a lightning rid of conservative criticism. [1]
    • 5/9/2025 EO 1427X Increasing Efficiency At The Office Of The Federal Register
  • Executive Order: Orders the Archivist of the US to reduce publication delays to the Federal Register to the greatest extent feasible, including by modernizing computer systems and eliminating unnecessary bureaucracy. [1]
    • 5/9/2025 EO 1427X Keeping Promises to Veterans and Establishing a National Center for Warrior Independence
  • Executive Order: Establishes a National Center for Warrior Independence on the West Los Angeles VA Campus for homeless veterans. Orders that all spent on housing or other services for illegal aliens are redirected to the National Center for Warrior Independence. Orders Housing and Urban Development to use vouchers for homeless veterans in LA. Orders reversal of Biden's decision to rehire and reinstate back pay for employees previously fired for misconduct. Orders a report on how to reduce VA wait times. [1]
  • West LA Veterans Affairs: The plan in this EO aims to house 6000 people over the coming years. The LA VA said that parts of the campus were being leased to a private school/companies, as well as the UCLA baseball team. In Sept 2024, a district judge ruled that leases to UCLA, Brentwood School and others on the VA property are illegal as they don't principally serve veterans. In March 2022, a plan to establish a homeless community for the West LA VA campus was announced, this is the same plan from Trump's EO. [1] [2]
    • 5/12/2025 EO 1427X Delivering Most-Favored Prescription Drug Pricing to American Patients
  • Executive Order: Makes it a policy to have Americans pay the same as other nations for the same prescription drugs. Directs the Secretary of Commerce and the FTC to make sure pharma companies do not engage in lower price destortions in other nations. Directs HHS to facilitate direct-to-consumer purchasing programs for pharmaceutical manufacturers that sell their products to American patients at the most-favored-nation price. Orders the HHS to communicate most-favored-nation price targets to pharmaceutical manufacturers to bring prices for American patients in line with comparably developed nations. If the pharma companies do not comply with the EO then Trump will make a rule to enforce it. [1]
  • Most favored nation pricing: Shares of drugmakers initially dropped in anticipation of the order but recovered after Trump released the order, due to skepticism over how he would implement the order. Trump said he was seeking cuts of between 59% and 90%. The US pays the highest prices for prescription drugs, often nearly three times more than other developed nations. During Trump's first term, he signed a similar EO but was stopped from implementing it by the courts. [1]
Pardons
  • Terence Sutton Jr and Andrew Zabavsky: [1] [2] [3]
    • Sutton was sentenced to 66 months in prison for second-degree murder, conspiracy to obstruct, and obstruction of justice in Sept 2024.
    • Zabavsky was sentenced to 48 months in prison for conspiracy to obstruct and obstruction of justice in Sept 2024.
    • In 2020, Sutton drove a police vehicle in "conscious disregard", hitting 20-year-old Black man named Karon Hylton-Brown.
    • Sutton and Zabavsky (both police officers) later conspired to hide the crash that lead to Hylton-Brown's death.
    • Sutton and Zabavsky later bragged about what they had done in an office wide email
  • Jan 6 Protestors: [1] [2] [3]
    • Trump pardoned all but 14 of the 1590 people involved in the Jan 6 capitol riots, including those who assaulted police officers, and those with charges from low-level trespassing offenses to seditious conspiracy
    • The 14 rioters not fully pardoned, all members of the Oath Keepers and Proud Boys, were not fully pardoned but will have their sentences ended early and will be freed from federal prison
    • Trump also ordered the Attorney General to drop all pending cases related to the riot
    • The White House released a proclamation for the pardons, which called the investigation into the riot a "grave national injustice" and said the pardons would begin a "process of national reconciliation"
    • Many Trump allies didn't expect such broad pardons, including Vice President JD Vance who previously said "If you committed violence on that day, obviously you shouldn't be pardoned"
    • The decision was criticized by the Fraternal Order of Police (FOP), the largest police union in the US.
    • Craig Sicknick called Trump "pure evil". His brother, Capitol Police Officer Brian Sicknick, died of a stroke the day after Jan 6 after being assaulted in the riot
    • A Reuters poll found that 60% of Americans say Trump should not have pardoned all the rioters
    • Among those released were Stewart Rhodes and Enrique Tarrio. Rhodes was the former leader of the far-right Oath Keepers and was sentenced to 18 years for plotting to use force to prevent the certification of the 2020 election, Trump only commuted his sentence and didn't give him a full pardon. Tarrio was the former leader of the far-right Proud Boys group and was sentenced to 22 years after being convicted of seditious conspiracy for planning the Jan 6 attack.
    • After the pardons, a federal judge imposed restrictions on Rhodes and 7 other Oath Keepers who were convicted of seditious conspiracy that they needed court approval before being able to enter the Capitol in Washington. However, the judge dropped the restrictions a few days later after finding that Trump's pardons also released them from a term of court supervision.
  • Ross Ulbricht: Ulbricht was sentence to life in prison for running the TOR site The Silk Road, which was used to conduct $214 million in drug and other illicit trade using bitcoin. Ulbricht was found guilty of charges including distributing drugs through the internet and conspiring to commit computer hacking and money laundering. Prosecutors said some people had died from the drugs they had bought on the Silk Road site, and that Ulbricht also ordered the murder of several people to keep the site running (though there is no evidence the murders were actually carried out). Trump had promised to pardon Ulbricht on the campaign trail while at the Libertarian National Convention. [1]
  • Lauren Handy anti-abortion protestors: 23 protestors who were convicted of blockading abortion clinic entrances and conspiring to overrun abortion clinics. One of those convicted, Lauren Handy, was discovered to have 5 fetuses in her home after she was indicted. Handy had been sentenced to 5 years in prison in May 2024 for conspiracy against rights (she made a fake appointment under a false name to get into the clinic) and violating the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances (FACE) Act due to her leading the blockade. Handy was convicted along with 9 co-defendants who also took part in the blockade on the Washington Surgi-Clinic that lasted for several hours. [1] [2] [3]
  • Rod Blagojevich: Blagojevich was the former Democrat Governor of Illinois. Blagojevich was convicted of corruption after trying to sell Obama's vacated US Senate seat after he won the 2008 Presidential election. In 2018, the Supreme Court rejected Blagojevich's bid to have his sentence reduced. Trump had communted Blagojevich's 14-year sentence during his first term. Blagojevich previously appeared as a contestant on Trump's "Celebrity Apprentice" while awaiting trial in 2010. [1]
  • Brian Kelsey: Kelsey was a former Republican state senator from Tennessee. He was indicted for using campaign funds from his state legislative seat toward his failed 2016 congressional bid. Kelsey was convicted of wire fraud and tax evasion in 2022 after pleading guilty, which he later unsuccessfully tried to rescind in 2023. Trump pardoned him after the first 2 weeks into his 6 year sentence. [1]
  • Devon Archer: Archer was convicted in 2018 in a scheme to defraud a Native American tribe involving the sale of bonds. In 2020, his conviction was overturned but then reinstated by a court of appeals. He was sentenced in 2022 to a year in prison. Archer was a former business partner of Hunter Biden nd testified before a Republican-led House commmittee in 2023 during their effort to impeach Joe Biden. Archer told the committee that Joe Biden was never directly involved in their financial dealings, though Hunter would often put his father on speakerphone to impress clients. At one point, Archer was asked point blank: "Are you aware of any wrongdoing by Vice President Biden?" He responded, "No, I'm not aware of any." [1]
  • Trevor Milton: Milton was previously the CEO of electric carmaker Nikola, before it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy In 2023, Milton was sentenced to 4 years in prison after a jury trial found him guilty for lying to investors about hist company's technology. Milton misled investors saying Nikola had built a pickup from the "ground up," that it had developed its own batteries even though he knew it was buying them, and that it had early success creating a "Nikola One" semi-truck that he knew did not work. A company video of a prototype truck appearing to be driven down a desert highway was actually a video of a nonfunctioning Nikola that had been rolled down a hill. In Oct 2024, Milton and his wife donated more than $1.8 million to the Trump re-election campaign. One of Milton's defense lawyers was also Brad Bondi, Pam Bondi's brother. [1] [2]
  • Carlos Watson: Watson had 10-year sentence that was commuted by Trump Watson was the founder of Ozy Media, he was a former cable news anchor and investment banker too. In 2024, he plead guilty of lying to investors about Ozy Media's finances and sham deals with Google and Oprah Winfrey. Watson's lawyers argued that he had been betrayed by his deputies who acted on their own. Ozy Media imploded in 2021 after it was revealed that a top executive had impersonated a YouTube executive during a call with Goldman Sachs bankers, in which he claimed the streaming site had agreed to pay for exclusive rights to an Ozy show. [1]
  • BitMEX Founders: Trump pardoned Benjamin Delo, Arthur Hayes and Samuel Reed all co-founders of BitMEX, he also pardoned BitMEX employee Gregory Dwyer. In 2022, the founders plead guilty to violating the Bank Secrecy Act, for failing to maintain anti-money laundering and KYC programs. BitMEX was a crypto exchange from 2015-2020. [1]
  • Michele Fiore: Fiore was a former Las Vegas city councilwoman and Republican Nevada lawmaker. Fiore had raised more than $70,000 for a statue of a Las Vegas police officer who was fatally shot in 2014 in the line of duty, but had instead spent some of it on cosmetic surgery, rent and her daughter's wedding. She was found guilty in Oct 2024 for federal wire fraud and conspiracy to commit wire fraud. Fiore had a campaign ad in 2022 where she steps out of a Ford F-150 with a handgun holstered on her hip and tells viewers she was one of the first elected officials to endorse Trump in 2016. In 2022, she lost a bid for state treasurer and was instead appointed as a judge in deep-red Nye County, despite not having a law degree. While serving as a state lawmaker, Fiore gained national attention for supporting rancher Cliven Bundy and his family during armed standoffs between militiamen and federal law enforcement officers in Bunkerville, Nevada, in 2014 and Malheur, Oregon, in 2016. [1] [2]
  • Pardon X: [1]
Foreign Policy
  • Russia:
    • On Trump's second day in office, he threatened that he would add tariffs on his sanctions threats against Russia if they didn't agree to a deal to end the war in Ukraine. Trump said in a Truth Social post "If we don't make a 'deal,' and soon, I have no other choice but to put high levels of Taxes, Tariffs, and Sanctions on anything being sold by Russia to the United States, and various other participating countries." The post came after Trump spent the entire campaign trail saying he would have a deal between the countries by his first day in office, which his admin now conceeded with take months or longer. The US imported just $2.9 billion from Russian in 2024, down from $29.6 billion in 2021; after Russia invaded Ukraine the US halted all Russian petroleum imports. [1]
    • On Feb 6, 2025, AG Pam Bondi ordered the DOJ to disband the Task Force KleptoCapture, which was established after the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine to sanction and target oligarchs close to the Kremlin. Bondi said that resources being used to target the Russian oligarchs would be transferred to targeting drug cartels at the US border. The task force brought indictments against aluminum magnate Oleg Deripaska and TV tycoon Konstantin Malofeyev for sanctions busting, and seized yachts belonging to sanctioned oligarchs Suleiman Kerimov and Viktor Vekselberg. The cases being investigated by the task force are likely to continue, but no longer be at the DOJ. The disbanding of the task force is likely to bring a sharp decline in the pace of charges brought on Russian oligarchs. [2]
    • On Feb 11, 2025, during a visit by Trump Middle east envoy Steve Witkoff, American schoolteacher Marc Fogel was released from Russia after 3.5 years in prison. Fogel was detained in Moscow in Aug 2021 and sentenced to 14 years in prison for posessing 17 grams of medical marijuana. In exchange for Fogel, the US released cybercrime kingpin Alexander Vinnik, who pleaded guilty in 2017 to conspiracy to commit money laundering and faced 20 years in prison. [1] [2]
    • On Feb 12, 2025, Trump said that Putin (first time US president has done so since Feb 2022) and Zelenskiy had expressed a desire for peace in separate phone calls. After the calls, Trump ordered his officials (Rubio, Ratcliffe, and Witkoff) to begin talks to end the Russia-Ukraine war. Earlier on the same day, Hegseth said that Ukraine would have to forget joining NATO and would have to forget getting their territory back that was taken by Russia and that there would be no US security troops sent to Ukraine. However, a day later John Coale, President Donald Trump's deputy Ukraine envoy, said that NATO membership and pre-2014 borders were still on the table. After Trump's remarks, Britain, France and Germany all said they needed to be part of the ceasefire talks. Later the next day, Zelenskiy said that the US, Europe and Ukraine need a common position before talks with Moscow, after Trump suggested setting up talks at the upcoming Munich security confrence. [1] [2] [3]
    • On Feb 14, 2025, in a WSJ interview, JD Vance said that the US would be able to wield economic and military leverage in talks with Russia to ensure a good peace deal over Ukraine, but his spokesman later denied he was making any threats against Moscow. The same day, during his keynote at the Munich Security Conference, Vance used his time to criticise the EU for their regulations on hate speech and misinformation, which he said amounted to censorship, instead of attacking Russia. [1]
    • On Feb 18, 2025, US officials including Rubio, Waltz and Witkoff, met with Russian officials in Saudi Arabia to discuss a Ukraine deal and restoring US-Russia relations. Ahead of the talks, Russian FM Lavrov said that Russia would not concede any territory to Ukraine, that no NATO country troops should be stationed in Ukraine, and that Europe should not play any role in the talks, setting a hard opening stance. Rubio said that the EU was not being sidelined and that the EU would be involved at some point. Russia also said that they not only wanted Ukraine to not join NATO, they wanted the US to withdraw a 2008 promise they made that Ukraine could join in the future. Ukraine was not present at the talks and said they would not accept any deal unless they were part if the negotiations. Rubio said during the meeting they discussed increasing embassy staffing at each other's embassies and to explore closer relations, including dropping sanctions. While the meeting was ongoing, Russia continued to bomb Ukrainian cities, killing civilians including children. [1] [2] [3]
    • On Mar 3, 2025, the Pentagon ordered a pause to all offensive cyber operations against Russia due to the negotiations with Ukraine. Offensive cyber operations, which disrupt or disable rivals' computer networks, are distinct from cyberespionage, which is aimed at intercepting data. The move came after Trump, Vance, and Zelenskiy had their argument in Washington. [1]
    • On Mar 13, 2025, Putin said that Russia supported the US proposal for a Ukraine ceasefire in principle, but couldn't accept until a number of crucial conditions were worked out or clarified. Zelenskiy had previously accepted the 30 day ceasefire the week before. [1]
    • On Mar 15, 2025, Trump demoted Keith Kellogg from special envoy for Ukraine and Russia to only Ukraine, after Russian officials had sought to exclude him from talks aiming to end the war due to the Russians complaining that he was to sympathetic to Ukraine. [1]
    • On Mar 18, 2025, Trump called Putin and Putin agreed to a Trump proposal for Russia and Ukraine to stop attacks on each other's energy infrastructure for 30 days and ordered the Russian military to cease them. Russia and Ukraine also agreed to exchange 175 for 175 POWs Putin's acceptance fell short of a full 30 day ceasefire for all operations in the Russia-Ukraine war. During the call, Putin outlined that he wanted an end to forced mobalization in Ukraine, Ukraine to drop its ambitions to join NATO, Russia to control the entirety of the four Ukrainian regions it has claimed as its own, the size of the Ukrainian army to be limited, and a complete cessation of foreign military equipment/intelligence to Ukraine. [1]
    • On Mar 19, 2025, the US halted work at several agencies to counter Russian sabotage, disinformation and cyberattacks, further easing pressure on Moscow. The halt included an end to NSC and EU national security meetings on Russian hybrid warfare. Over the last three years, Russia recruited criminals in European countries for sabotage operations including arson, attempted assassinations and planting bombs on cargo aircraft. Russia had previously polttedto assassinate the CEO of Rheinmetall, a German manufacturer whose weapons were being used by Ukraine, before the plans were twarted by law enforcement. Russia also used influence campaigns and cyber operations to erode support for Ukraine. [1]
    • On Mar 25, 2025, the WH announced it made agreements with both Ukraine and Russia to ensure safe navigation in the Black Sea and to implement a ban strikes against energy facilities in the two countries. They also said they would lift some sanctions to restore Russia's access to the world market for agricultural and fertilizer exports. [1]
    • On April 10, 2025, the US and Russia made a prisoner swap. Russia released Ksenia Karelina, a dual US-Russia citizen who was found guilty in 2024 of treason by a Russian court for donating $51.80 to a U.S.-based charity providing humanitarian support to Ukraine. The US released Arthur Petrov, a dual German-Russian citizen arrested in 2023 in Cyprus at the request of the U.S. for allegedly exporting sensitive microelectronics. [1]
    • On April 18, 2025, Trump and Rubio said the US would walk away fro peace talks unless there was clear progress soon. The comments came as there was growing frusturation in the WH over Russia's unwillingness to end the war and with Zelensky's comments earlier in the week that Witkoff was "spreading Russian narratives." The comments also came after the WH said they were ready to recognize Crimea as Russian territory. On April 20, 2025, Putin declared an "Easter ceasefire," that would take place over the next day until Easter Sunday was over. On Easter Sunday, Ukraine said Russia had continued atrillery attacks and Russia said that Ukraine forces continued to fight including along the Crimean border and in Kursk. [1] [2]
    • On April 24, 2025, Russia stikes hit Kyiv, causing Trump to tweet "Vladimir, STOP!" and "I am not happy with the Russian strikes on KYIV. Not necessary, and very bad timing." The rebuke came a day after Trump criticised Zelenskiy for saying Ukraine would not recognize Russia's occupation of Crimea. Trump sayd Crimea was lost years ago "and is not even a point of discussion." [1]
    • On April 28, 2025, Trump suggested Zelenskiy might be willing to give up Crimea, which would be political suicide, and rebuked Putin for firing missiles at Kyiv. Hours after the comments, Putin announced a May 8-10 ceasefire for the Victory Day celebration (end of WW2), signalling he was still interested in peace. [1] [2]
  • Ukraine:
    • On Feb 1, 2025, Trump's Ukraine envoy, Keith Kellogg, told Ukraine to hold new elections potentially before the end of the year. Zelenskiy's five-year term was supposed to end in 2024 but presidential and parliamentary polls cannot be held under martial law, which Ukraine imposed in February 2022. In Feb 2025, Trump also said "We're looking to do a deal with Ukraine where they're going to secure what we're giving them with their rare earth and other things." Suggesting that he wanted Ukraine to allow the US to take rare earth metal from Ukraine as a condition of further support, Treasury secretary Bessent later visited Ukraine to discuss a minerals deal. [1] [2] [3]
    • On Feb 17, 2025, European leaders met in Paris for an emergency meeting to discuss a unified strategy to a Ukraine-Russia peacedeal. The meeting came after Trump's admin headed to Saudi Arabia for talks with Russian officials on ending the war, after the Trump called Putin without consulting the EU first and left any European country out of the talks in Saudi Arabia. At the meeting, UK PM Starmer said he was willing to send British peacekeeping troops to Ukraine if a deal materialized, which could raise the risk of a direct confrontation with Russia. Germany also said they were willing to commit peacekeeping troops. [1]
    • On Feb 19, 2025, relations between Zelenskiy and Trump began to deteriorate after Zelenskiy said Trump was living in a Russian-made "disinformation space" and Trump called Zelenskiy a "dictator without elections." Trump began the exchange saying that Zelenskiy was a dictator for not having elections and that the only thing Zelenskiy "was good at was playing Biden 'like a fiddle.'" Trump also said Zelenskiy had a 4% approval rating (current polling showed it was actually 57%) and that Ukraine "should have never started" the war and "could have made a deal" to prevent it. Zelenskiy responded by saying "We have seen this disinformation. We understand that it is coming from Russia," and that Trump "lives in this disinformation space." On Feb 20, 2025, despite his comments, Trumps envoy Kellogg met with Zelenskiy, which Zelenskiy said was a productive conversation about prisoners of war, security guarantees, and the battlefield situation. However, a joint press confrence planned after the meeting was cancelled at the US request. [1] [2]
    • On Feb 21, 2025, Trump reversed his previous statement, saying Russia did in fact invade Ukraine but that Ukraine and Biden should not have allowed them to attack. Trump also called for a mineral deal, after Zelenskiy rejected a US demands for $500 billion in mineralS from Ukraine to repay for wartime aid, saying the US had supplied nowhere near that sum and offered no specific security guarantees. [1]
    • On Feb 24, 2025, on the 3rd anniversary of the war, the US voted no on UN general assembly resolutions condemning Russia's aggression in Ukraine. [1]
    • On Feb 28, 2025, Zelensky met with Trump in the Oval Office to finalize their mineral deal and ended in a disasterous screaming match. The exchange started when Zelensky tried to persuade Trump not to side with Putin and asked JD Vance how the US was going to give a security guarantee, "What kind of diplomacy are you talking about, JD?" Vance responded by calling Zelensky disrespectful and ungrateful for US support, acting as an attack dog for Trump, "I'm talking about the kind of diplomacy that's going to end the destruction of your country." After the meeting, Zelensky was asked by Trump to leave the WH early and the mineral deal was not signed, despite the Ukrainans wanting to continue the talks. The outburst occured after weeks of increasing tensions, with Trump and Zelensky trading blows on social media; Trump also told his team to limit communications with Zelenskiy's top aide Andriy Yermak and tried to get Ukrainian elections as part of a peace deal to see Zelensky ousted. European leaders responded to the meeting by rushing to support Zelensky, including newly elected German chancellor candidate Friedrich Merz, Canada's Trudeau, UK PM Starmer, and France's Macron. US Dem lawmakers condemed Trump for the meeting, while Republicans were split with some backing Kyiv and others backing Trump, dimming the prospect of future US aid to Ukraine. After the meeting Trump tweeted "I have determined that President Zelenskyy is not ready for Peace if America is involved ... He can come back when he is ready for Peace." Hours after the meeting, Zelenskiy said in an interview by Fox News "Yes of course" that his relationship with Trump could be salvaged, adding "I'm sorry for this." Former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev said Zelensky had received a "brutal dressing down," after the meeting. During the meeting, a Russian State TV TASS reporter snuck into the Oval Office but was later escorted out, Reuters and the AP were not allowed into the meeting. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5]
    • On Mar 1, 2025 Zelensky tweeted "Thank you America, thank you for your support, thank you for this visit. Thank you @POTUS, Congress, and the American people. Ukraine needs just and lasting peace, and we are working exactly for that." However, Trump allies including national security adviser Mike Waltz and House Majority leader Mike Johnson called on Zelensky to change his mind on the war and Russia or step down from power so a new leader could work with the US. The same day, the private Norwegian fuel supplier Haltbakk Bunkers said they would stop fueling the US Navy, but this was contradicted when the Norwegian defense minister said they would continue fueling the US ships. [1] [2] [3]
    • On Mar 3, 2025, Trump suspended all military aid to Ukraine, many Urainians viewed it as a betrayal. However, sources still said Trump and Zelensky planned to signe the mineral deal. After the pause, Zelensky called the meeting he had with trump "regrettable" and that he wanted to "make things right." [1] [2]
    • On Mar 4, 2025, Trump said he got a letter from Zelenskiy expressing Ukraine's willingness to sign the mineral deal. [1]
    • On Mar 5, 2025, the CIA paused all US intelligence sharing with Ukraine, amid growing US pressure to have Zelensky work with the US and Russia in peace talks. [1]
    • On Mar 12, 2025, the US resumed arms and intelligence aid to Ukraine after they agreed to a 30-day ceasefire with Russia. Ukraine agreed to the deal during a Ukraine-US meeting in Saudi Arabia. [1]
    • On April 10, 2025, U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine Bridget Brink resigned on her own accord. [1]
    • Minerals deal signed: On May 1, 2025, Ukraine and the US finally signed a critical minerals deal, giving the US preferential access to new Ukrainian minerals deals and fund investment in Ukraine's reconstruction. The deal allowed Ukraine to "determine what and where to extract" and that its subsoil remains owned by Ukraine. Also, Ukraine has no debt obligations to the United States under the agreement, a key sticking point. However, the deal didn't provide any concrete security guarantees for Ukraine. [1]
  • Israel/Palestine:
    • On Trump's first day in office, he rescinded sanctions Biden had placed on WB settlers who were accused of violence against Pals (Biden executive order 14115). Trump also lifted the Biden era halt on 2000-pound bombs being sent to Israel. [1] [2]
    • After the Gaza ceasefire took hold in Jan 2025, Trump told Jordan, Egypt and other Arab nations that they should increase the number of Pal refugees thay took in, saying they needed to "just clean out that whole thing". Hamas, Egypt, and Jordan all rejected the notion. Far-right Israeli minister Smotrich welcomed Trump's idea, wanting to move Jewish settlements back into Gaza, which Israeli PM Netanyahu rejects. [1] [2]
    • On Feb 5, 2025, Trump said he envisioned the US taking over Gaza and transforming it into the "Riviera of the Middle East" resort where international communities could coexist after the destruction of the Gaza war. Trump originally said that Palestinians should be permanently removed from Gaza but his press secratary Karoline Leavitt walked back Trump's assertion saying that instead they should be "temporarily relocated" for the rebuilding process. Jordan and Egypt both said they didn't back displacing Palestinians in response to the comments. Saudi Arabia said they would refuse to establish ties with Israel if Trump went through with the plan and without the creation of a Palestinian state. Ben-Gvir, a far-right Israeli lawmaker, said "encouraging" Gazans to emigrate was the only correct strategy at the end of the Gaza war and urged Netanyahu to adopt the policy "immediately." The plan was also praised by PM Netanyahu, who said "Give them a choice. Not forcible eviction. Not ethnic cleansing." Analysts suspect that Trump only made the comments to increase leverage to use as a negotiating tool in later negotiations. On Feb 9, 2025, Trump repeated his plan to take over Gaza, saying "I'm committed to buying and owning Gaza. As far as us rebuilding it, we may give it to other states in the Middle East to build sections of it, other people may do it, through our auspices. But we're committed to owning it, taking it, and making sure that Hamas doesn't move back." [1] [2] [3] [4]
    • On 2/11/2025, Trump met with Jordan's King Abdullah. During the meeting, Trump asked Abdullah to take in Pals from Gaza, after saying that Pals would not be allowed to return to Gaza if the US took it over. Abdullah outright rejected the proposal, Trump said he would threaten withholding aid from Jordan if they didn't comply. [1]
    • On Feb 19, 2025, Trump stopped all funding to the PA security forces as part of his global freeze on foreign assistance. [1]
    • On Feb 24, 2025, Trump rescinded Biden National Security Memorandum-20, which he issued amid criticism over Israel's use of American bombs in Gaza. NSM-20 required the US to report to Congress potential violations of international law involving US-supplied weapons by allies.
    • In Mar 2025, Trump's hostage envoy Adam Boehler directlt met with Hamas, which broke with a decades-old policy by Washington against negotiating with groups the U.S. brands as terrorist organizations. [1]
    • On Mar 14, 2025, Hamas said they would American-Israeli dual national, Edan Alexander, if Israel begins the second phase of ceasefire talks towards a permanent end to the war. Israel had refused to begin the second phase of talks after the first phase expired on Mar 2, upon which Israel blockaded the Gaza Strip. Israel instead wants to extend the first phase which was a proposal from Trump envoy Steve Witkoff. Netanyahu's office said the Hamas offer to release Alexander was "manipulation and psychological warfare." [1]
    • Also on Mar 14, 2025, the AP reported that Trump and Israel officials had contacted Sudan, Somalia and the breakaway region of Somalia known as Somaliland asking them to potentially take in Palestinians as part of a postwar plan in Gaza. Since all three places are poor, and wracked by violence, the proposal also casts doubt on Trump's stated goal of resettling Gazans in a "beautiful area." Sudan said they had rejected the US offer while Somalia and Somaliland said they were unaware of any offer. US and Israel officials confirmed the Somalia and Somaliland contracts and only US officials confirmed the Sudan contract. Sudan was previously among the countries in the 2020 Abraham Accords. [1]
    • On April 2, 2025, Trump imposed 17% tariffs on Israeli imports, despite Israel dropping all US tariffs days before. [1]
    • Edan Alexander released: On May 12, 2025, Israeli-American hostage, Edan Alexander, was released from Gaza by Hamas during a brief pause in fighting, with Israeli resuming strikes on Gaza right after he was exchanged. Alexander was the last living US hostage still being kept by Hamas, who said they released him as a good-will gesture to Trump, who was visiting the Gulf States that week. The release came after four-way talks between Hamas, the US, Egypt and Qatar, with Qatar and Egypt saying Alexander's release was an encouraging step towards new truce talks. After the release, Netanyahu said there will be no ceasefire and that plans to intensify military action in Gaza will continue. [1]
  • Yemen:
    • On Mar 15, 2025, Trump launched large-scale military strikes against the Houthis due to their continued disruption of red Sea shipping, killing 31 people. Trump also threatened Iran saying, "America will hold you fully accountable and, we won't be nice about it!" In an effort to mend ties with Russia, Rubio told Russia about the strikes beforehand. [1]
    • On April 17, 2025, the US launched strikes on emen's Ras Isa fuel terminal, killing 74 people in the deadliest strikes since the us began bombing Yemen in 2024. The strikes came depite the Houthis having halted their strikes on Red Sea shipping since the 2 month Gaza ceasefire brokered under Biden. [1]
    • US-Houthi Red Sea deal: On May 6, 2025, the US and the Houthis made a deal that the US would stop bombing the Houthis due the the group agreeing to stop attacking shipping lanes in the Red Sea. Oman said they had mediated the ceasefire, where neither side is allowed to attack one another. However, the Houthis said they would continue to target Israel, including a strike that landed on Ben Gurion airport the day before. [1]
  • Iran:
    • Trump letter to Khamenei: In early March 2025, Trump sent a letter to Ayatollah Khamenei saying "there are two ways Iran can be handled: militarily, or you make a deal." Khamenei responded by rejecting holding nuclear deal negotiations with Trump. The letter was transferred from the US to the UAE to Iran. The arrival came as Trump levied new sanctions on Iran as part of his "maximum pressure" campaign. [1] [2]
    • New Iran sanctions: On Mar 20, 2025, Trump issued new Iran sanctions, his fourth round of sanctions since returning to office. They included sanctions on the China-based Shandong Shouguang Luqing Petrochemical Co., Ltd, a so-called 'teapot' refinery that purchased Iranian oil. China is the largest importer of Iranian oil and does not recognize US sanctions, they also use a system of middlemen and the yuan to avoid the US dollar.. The sanctions also targeted vessels iran uses as part of their "shadow fleet," used to transport their oil. [1]
    • Trump threatens to bomb Iran: On Mar 30, 2025, Trump threatened Iran with bombing and secondary tariffs if they didn't sign a nuclear deal. "If they don't make a deal, there will be bombing," Trump said in a telephone interview. "It will be bombing the likes of which they have never seen before." Iran responded by rejecting Trump's threat, saying they refused to engage in direct negiations with the US. [1]
    • Nuclear talks: On April 7, 2025, Trump made a suprise announcement that Iran and the US would be having direct talks in Oman over Iran's nuclear program. However, Tehran later said the talks would be indirect, with Oman as mediator. On 4/12/2025, the talks were held indirectly and mediated by Oman, as Iran had wanted, with both sides saying they were "positive" and "constructive" and agreed to continue them the following week. Oman said the talks involved de-escalating regional tensions, prisoner exchanges and limited agreements to ease sanctions on Iran in exchange for ending their nuke program. On April 19, 2025, the US and Iran held their second round of nuclear talks in Rome, where Iran said they would only accept a deal if there were guarantees that Trump would not abandon it again, a demand that Biden failed on. During the Rome talks, the two sides agreed to begin drawing up a framework for a potential nuclear deal. [1] [2] [3] [4]
    • LPG magnate sanctions: On April 22, 2025, the US issued new sanctions on Iranian liquefied petroleum gas magnate Seyed Asadoollah Emamjomeh and his corporate network. The sanctions came amid ongoing nuclear talks between the US and Iran. Emamjomeh's network is responsible for shipping hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of Iranian LPG and crude oil to foreign markets.
  • China:
    • On Feb 1, 2025, Trump imposed a 10% tariff on all Chinese imports due to the Chinese contribution to the US fentanyl crisis. China said it would challenge Trump's move at the World Trade Organization and take other "countermeasures," without giving details. The Chinese Commerce Ministry said they wanted to "engage in frank dialogue, strengthen cooperation and manage differences," leaving the door open to negotiation. "Fentanyl is America's problem," China's foreign ministry said, adding that China has taken extensive measures to combat the problem. [1] [2]
    • On Feb 4, 2025, China retaliated with targeted tariffs on US imports, apploying to about $20 billion in annual imports (compared to $450 billion from the Trump tariffs), and put several US companies, including Google, PVH (Calvin Klein), and Illumina, on notice for anti-monopoly sanctions. The Chinese tariffs in US goods include a 15% levy on U.S. coal and LNG and 10% for crude oil, farm equipment and a small number of trucks as well as big-engine sedans. The limited response from Chine underscores their attempt to engage Trump in talks, which were not yet scheduled, before engaging in an all out trade war. [1]
    • On Mar 4, 2025, Trump increased the China tariffs to 20% from 10%. China immediately responded to the increase with additional tariffs of 10%-15% on certain U.S. imports and a series of new export restrictions for designated U.S. entities. Later it said it had raised complaints about the new measures with the World Trade Organization. The Chinese retaliatory tariffs included 15% on US-made chicken, wheat, corn and cotton, and 10% on sorghum, soybeans, pork, beef, seafood, fruit, vegetables and dairy. Their export restrictions also included 25 U.S. firms under export and investment restrictions on national security grounds. The companies included TCOM, Limited Partnership; Stick Rudder Enterprises LLC; Teledyne Brown Engineering; Huntington Ingalls Industries; S3 AeroDefense; Cubic Corporation; TextOre; ACT1 Federal; Exovera; Planate Management Group; General Dynamics Land Systems and General Atomics Aeronautical Systems, among others. [1] [2]
    • On April 3, 2025, China announced 34% tariffs on all US imports in response to Trump's reciprocal tariffs. Trump doubled down, saying he would not change course and raised by 50% his earlier tariff on China to 104%. China responded to this by raising their US tariff rate by 50% to 84% too and imposed restrictions on 18 US companies. On April 9, Trump again raised tariffs on China from 84% to 125%, China retaliated by raising US tariffs to 125% too. China said this would be the last time they responded to a US tariff increase and they would begin working with the EU and Asia to fight the US further. [1] [2] [3] [4]
    • On April 25, 2025, China exempted some US imports including pharmaceuticals. In an interview in TIME magazine, Trump said Xi had called him to begin talks on a trade deal, China's FM denied that the US and China were talking however. [1]
    • China Trade war ceasefire: On May 12, 2025, the US and China agreed to a temporary truce in their tariff trade war, after days of talks mediated in Switzerland. The deal leaves US tariffs on China at 30% and China tariffs on the US at 10% from May 14 to August 12. [1]
  • Canada:
    • On Feb 1, 2025, Trump started a trade war by imposing a 25% tariff on all goods coming from Canada, except energy goods, which only got a 10% tariff. Trump cited Canada's failure to curb fentanyl flow into the US as why he imposed the tariffs. Canadian PM Justin Trudeau, said Canada would respond with tariffs on $155 billion of US goods, including beer, wine, lumber and appliances, beginning with $30 billion taking effect 2/4/25 and $125 billion 21 days later. Trudeau urged Canadians to forego travel to the US and boycott US products. Trudeau also said how him and many Canadians felt beytrayed, reminding Americans that Canadian troops fought alongside them in Afghanistan and helped respond to myriad crises from wildfires in California to Hurricane Katrina. Canada and Mexico said they will be working together against Trump's tariffs. Trump had previously floated the idea also that Canada should become the 51st state of the US. However, after negotiations, Trump agreed to pause the tariffs for 1 month due to Canada offering a $900 million border security package and a new "fentanyl czar". [1] [2] [3] [4]
    • On March 4, 2025, the tariffs went into effect, sending Canadian and US markets tumbling, erasing all the gains made since Trump's election. Canada retaliated with 25% tariffs on C$155 billion ($107 billion) worth of U.S. goods. The Canadian tariffs on the US immediately too affect on C$30 billion ($20.7 billion) worth of U.S. imports, with the rest coming in 21 days, including orange juice, peanut butter, wine, spirits, beer, coffee, appliances and motorcycles. Trudeau responded by telling Trump, 'This is a very dumb thing to do' Ontario Premier Doug Ford banned U.S. firms from bidding on provincial government contracts and said that if tariffs persist, he will apply a 25% surcharge to Ontario electricity exports to the U.S. [1] [2]
    • Ontario Premier Doug Ford, placed an additional 25% tariff on electricity it generates for more than 1 million homes in New York state, Michigan and Minnesota, saying he would not back down until all of Trump's tariffs on Canadian imports to the U.S. were "gone for good." Trump responded by saying he would double tariffs on steel and aluminum from Canada to 50%. After the Trump threat, Ford and Trump met and agreed to reverse their decisions, with US tariffs on Canadian aluminum and steel goinf back to 25%. [1]
    • On Mar 12, 2025, the steel and aluminum tariffs went into effect. Canada responded with C$29.8 bln in retaliatory tariffs. Canada is the largest supplier of steel and aluminum to the US. [1]
    • First Trump Carney meeting: On May 6, 2025, Carney traveled to the WH for his first visit with Trump. Carney said the meeting was constructive and Trump said the meeting was great. During the meeting Carney asked Trump not to refer to Canada as the 51st state in public, but said Trump will say what he wants. Also during the meeting Carney said Canada was "not for sale, it won't be for sale - ever," with Trump replying "Never say never, never say never." [1]
  • Mexico:
    • In Trump's first week of office, he renamed the Gulf of Mexico to the Guld of America. The change was not internationally recognized, but Google Maps changed the name of "Gulf of Mexico" to "Gulf of America" for US users. [1] [2]
    • On 2/1/2025, Trump started a trade war with Mexico by imposing 25% tariffs on all Mexico imports, including oil, citing a national emergency from fentanyl and illegal immigration flow into the US. Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum ordered retalitory tariffs in reponse to Trump, without specifying how much or on what goods. Sheinbaum also rejected as "slander" the White House's allegation that drug cartels have an alliance with the Mexican government, which Trump had claimed as justification for the tariffs. Canada and Mexico said they will be working together against Trump's tariffs. However, after negotiations, Trump agreed to pause the tariffs for 1 month due to Mexico sending 10,000 national guard troops to the border. [1] [2] [3]
    • On March 4, 2025, the tariffs went into effect due to Trump feeling Mexico hadn't done enough to stop the flow of fentanyl. [1]
  • Columbia:
    • In Jan 2025, Trump began sending deported migrant flights using military aircraft from the US to Columbia. This resulted in the Columbian President Gustavo Petro to reject the flights, saying they were inhumane. Trump reacted to this by threatening 25% tariffs on all Colombian goods coming into the U.S. (US is Colombia's largest trade partner), which would go up to 50% in one week; a travel ban and visa revocations on Colombian government officials; and emergency treasury, banking and financial sanctions. Petro announced a retaliatory 25% increase in Colombian tarrifs on US good following Trump's tariff announcement. Colombia is the fourth-largest overseas supplier of crude oil and also the largest supplier of fresh cut flowers to the US. Eventually, an agreement was made to transport the migrants back to Colombia on military planes, though Colombia said their presidential plane was open to be used to transport the deportees. After the agreement, Trump dropped his threats, stepping back from the brink of a trade-war. Colombia accepted 475 deportation flights from the U.S. from 2020 to 2024, fifth behind Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico and El Salvador. [1] [2]
  • Venezuela:
    • Trump's Latin America envoy, Richard Grenell, return to US from Venezuela visit with 6 American citizens in a suprise development. The 6 Americans were accused of terrorism and said some were high-level "mercenaries." "President Donald Trump, we have made a first step, hopefully it can continue," Maduro said in response to the release. The White House stressed that the visit with Maduro didn't mean they recognized him as their legitimate leader. Following the visit, Trump also announced that Venezuela agreed to receive all Venezualan illegal immigrants captured in the US and provide for their transportation. [1] [2]
    • On Feb 2, 2025, Trump terminated deportation relief for 300,000 Venzuelans with with Temporary Protected Status (TPS) in the US Those affected would lose their deportation relief and access to work permits 60 days after the federal government publishes the termination notice. TPS is available to people whose home country has experienced a natural disaster, armed conflict or other extraordinary event. [1]
    • On Mar 22, 2025, Venezuela agreed to resume repatriation flights for migrants from the US. [1]
  • Panama:
    • After taking office in 2025, Trump threatened to take control of the Panama Canal, refusing to rule out military force over Panama. On 2/2/25, Marco Rubio told Panama President Jose Raul Mulino that the US would "take measures necessary" if Panama doesn't take steps to end what Trump sees as Chinese influence over the Panama Canal. Mulino signaled he would review agreements involving China and Chinese businesses following the talks with Rubio. Mulino also said he would consider terminating an agreement between Panama and China to contribute to China's Belt and Road initiative. Rubio said Trump thinks that China's presence - through a Hong Kong-based company operating two ports near the canal's entrances - was a threat to the waterway and a violation of the U.S.-Panama neutrality treaty. Trump commented on the Canal by saying "China's running the Panama Canal. That was not given to China, that was given to Panama - foolishly - but they violated the agreement, and we're going to take it back, or something very powerful is going to happen." In 2021, the Hong Kong-based CK Hutchison Holdings renewed a 25 year concession for operation of 2 ports at both entrances of the canal, which said could allow China to close the canal to US traffic if the US and China entered into a war. However, Panama says the ports are not part of the canal's operation and that the ports are operated by the Panama Canal Authority, an autonomous agency overseen by the Panamanian government. [1]
    • On Feb 6, 2025, the Mulino said the US was spreading "lies and falsehoods", after the state department said US government vessels would be able to pass through the Panama Canal without paying. US military vessels do have priority of passage through the waterway, according the 1977 neutrality treaty, but still have to pay their toll. Marco Rubio later said in a press confrence that it was "absurd" that the US Navy pay to use the canal. [2]
  • El Salvador:
    • On Feb 3, 2025, the US and El Salvador struck a deal allowing the US to ship both detained migrants and imprisoned citizens to El Salvador prisons. In 2023, El Salvador President Nayib Bukele opened he Terrorism Confinement Center (CECOT) mega-prison able to hold 44,000 prisoners, in 2024 El Salvador had 110,000 prisoners in total in their country. In CECOT, there are no rehabilitation or educational programs and the prisoners are never let outside, Bukele's admin has said that the prisoners held in CECOT will never return to their communities. [1]
    • On April 24, 2025, Trump met with Bukele in Washington. During the visit, Bukele said he would not return a man mistakenly deported to El Salvador that the Supreme Court ruled must be brought back. Bukele said doing so would be like smuggling a terrorist into the country. The Trump admin indicated they would not be asking for Abrego Garcia to be returned as well. [1]
  • Somalia:
      On Feb 1, 2025, the US military conducted airstrikes targeting a senior ISIL planner and recuits in Somalia. Hegseth said the strikes were directed by Trump and coordinated with the Somalian government. The Pentagon said that multiple ISIL operatives were killed and that no civilians were harmed in the strikes. The strikes come after previous ones on Jan 30 in northwest Syria on Hurras al-Din operatives.
    • [1]
  • Japan:
    • In Feb 2025, Japanese PM Shigeru Ishiba visited Trump, in which Trump announced that $14.9 billion bid for US Steel would take the form of an investment instead of a purchase. However, sources still said Nippon had still not withdrawn their bid. Trump mistakenly referred to Nippon as "Nissan" during his remarks. Before the 2024 election, the buyout became highly politicized, with both Trump and Biden vowing to kill the deal. Biden also in Jan 2025 blocked the $14.9 billion deal from going through. [1]
  • India:
      Feb 2025 Modi visit: On Feb 13, 2025, in a visit at the WH, India's PM Narendra Modi agreed to increase their purchase of US energy $25 bln from $15 bln and to increase purchases of US defense products.
    • [1]
    • Pakistan-India ceasefire: On May 11, 2025, Trump said the US had mediated a ceasefire with Pakistan and India, after fighting broke out between the two sides over the disputed Kashmir region. Pakistan thanked the US for their help in mediation but India denied the US had any involvement, saying that they had direct talks with Pakistan. Within hours of the ceasefire being agreed to, both sides accused each other of violating it, yet it appeared the ceaseifre still held. [1]
  • France:
    • On Feb 24, 2025, Macron met with Trump in Washington, with the two remaining friendly but Macron heavyly disagreeing with Trump on Ukraine. Trump said he wanted a quick ceasefire ASAP while macron wanted a truce then a creasefire with security guarantees, to ensure fighting didn't break out again. The two agreed on Europe providing peacekeeping troops as part of a deal. [1]
  • EU:
    • On Mar 12, 2025, the steel and aluminum tariffs went into effect. The EU responds with tariffs on up to 26 bln euros of US exports. However, the tariffs only affect 2% of the EU trade to the US. [1]
    • On April 9, 2025, when the reciprocal tariffs went into effect, the EU approved a 25% tariff on a range of US import in response. ON April 10, the EU paused their retalitory teriffs for 90 days after Trump announced his own 90 day tariff pause. [1] [2]
  • Afghanistan:
    • On Mar 20, 2025, George Glezmann, a US citizen who was abducted by the Taliban in 2022 as a tourist in Afghanistan, was freed as part of a "goodwill gesture" by the Taliban. The deal was brokered by Qatari negotiators and Adam Boehler, Trump's hostage negotiator. The Taliban said the release was part of their "normalization" of ties with the US following their 2021 Afghanistan withdrawl. Two other American detained by the Taliban, Ryan Corbett and William McKenty, were released after a deal was struck to exchange an Afghani heroin smuggler during the final days of the Biden admin. [1]
  • Denmark/Greenland:
    • In March 2025, Usha Vance, the wife of JD Vance, planned a trip to a popular dog-sled race in Greenland, Denmark said this move was part of an "unacceptable pressure" on the semi-autonomous Danish territory. JD Vance then announced he would lead the delegation and they would only visit the U.S. Space Base at Pituffik in northern Greenland, which Denmark responded positively to. "This is clearly a de-escalation," Danish Foreign Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen said. Polls show that nearly all Greenlanders oppose becoming part of the US, and anti-American protesters, have recently staged some of the largest demonstrations ever seen in Greenland. [1]
  • Lesotho:
    • On April 2, 2025, Trump imposed 50% tariffs on Lesotho. Lesotho exported $237 million to the US in 2024, mostly textiles for popular brands such as Levi's and Calvin Klein, making up 1/10th of their GDP and 45% of their total exports. Previously, in his March 2025 address to Congress, Trump referred to Lesotho as a country "no one has heard of," which Lesotho's FM Lejone Mpotjoane said was "quite insulting." Lesotho is one of the world's poorest countries, with 2 million people and a GDP per capita of $916. [1]
  • Tunisia:
    • In April 2025, the US gained release of American Robert Vieira, who was detained in Tunisia in 2024 due to suspected espionage. [1]
  • UK:
    • Tariff deal: On May 8, 2025, the US and UK announced a deal to lower some tariffs. The US would keep the base 10% tariff, reduce tariffs on some UK-made cars from 27.5% to 10%, reduce steel tariffs from 25% to 0%, reduce plane part tariffs to 0%, The UK would buy $10 billion in Boeing planes, remove all tariffs on ethanol (used in beer) from 19%, still not allow US beef imports with growth hormones. [1] [2]
  • Qatar:
    • Air Force One gift: On May 11, 2025, the Qatar royal family said they were giving Trump a new commercial 747-8 (costs $400 million). The plane would be used to replace Air Force One, then it will become part of the Trump's presidental library after his term ends. The gift came days before Trump was headed to the Qatar during his Middle East visit. The Constitution bans U.S. officials from accepting gifts from foreign governments without congressional approval. [1]
  • Saudi Arabia:
    • 2025 Trump visit: In May 2025, Trump went on a tour of the Gulf States, visiting Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and the UAE. During the visit, Trump signed a deal with Riyadh on energy, defence, mining and other areas, where Saudi Arabia would buy $142 billion in arms from the US in exchange for a commitment by Saudi Arabia to invest $600 billion in the US. [1]
  • Syria:
    • Trump meets : On May 14, Trump met the Syrian interim President Ahmed al-Sharaa during his visit to Saudi Arabia. During the meeting, Trump made a suprise announcement that the US was dropping all sanctions on Syria. Trump also asked al-Sharaa to normalize relations with Israel during the meeting. [1]

Legislature

119th Congress
House [1]
  • 220-215 Republican majority.
  • House speaker: Mike Johnson (Louisiana) was re-elected
  • Majority Leader: Steve Scalise (Louisiana)
  • Minority Leader: Hakeem Jefferies (NY)
  • Had first openly trans member of Congress in history, Representative Sarah McBride of Delaware.
Senate [1]
  • 53-47 Republican majority.
